In this section—

P3para.Text: “UK institution” means an institution which is incorporated in, or formed under the law of any part of, the United Kingdom;
“insurer” means an institution which is authorised under this Act to carry on the regulated activity of effecting or carrying out contracts of insurance as principal.

P2para.Text: Subsections (1) and (3)(b) are to be read in accordance with section 22, taken with Schedule 2 and any order under section 22.
Section 347 of FSMA 2000 (the record of authorised persons etc.) is amended as follows.
In subsection (2)—

P3para.Text: in paragraph (g), after sub-paragraph (iii) insert—

P4para.Text: in a case where the relevant authorised person is a bank, whether or not the person is a senior manager;

P3para.Text: after that paragraph insert—
in the case of an approved person who is a senior manager in relation to an authorised person that is a bank—

P4para.Text: whether a final notice has been given to the person under section 390; and
if so, any information about the matter to which the notice relates which has been published under section 391(4).

P2para.Text: After subsection (8) insert—
In this section—

Para.Text: “senior manager”, in relation to an authorised person that is a bank, means a person who has approval under section 59 to perform a designated senior management function in relation to the carrying on by the bank of a regulated activity,
“bank” has the same meaning as in Part 5 (see section 71A), and
“designated senior management function” means a function designated as a senior management function under section 59(6B) or (6C).

P1para.Text: Schedule 3 (which contains further amendments relating to the provisions of this Part) has effect.

P1group.Title: Offence relating to decision that results in bank failure

P2para.Text: A person (“S”) commits an offence if—

P3para.Text: at a time when S is a senior manager in relation to a bank (“B”), S—

P4para.Text: takes, or agrees to the taking of, a decision by or on behalf of B as to the way in which the business of a group bank is to be carried on, or
fails to take steps that S could take to prevent such a decision being taken,

P3para.Text: at the time of the decision, S is aware of a risk that the implementation of the decision may cause the failure of the group bank,
in all the circumstances, S’s conduct in relation to the taking of the decision falls far below what could reasonably be expected of a person in S’s position, and
the implementation of the decision causes the failure of the group bank.

P2para.Text: A “group bank”, in relation to a bank (“B”), means B or any other bank that is a member of B’s group for the purpose of FSMA 2000 (see section 421 of that Act).
Subsections (1) and (2) are to be read with the interpretative provisions in section 28.
A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable—

P3para.Text: on summary conviction—

P4para.Text: in England and Wales, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months (or 6 months, if the offence was committed before the commencement of section 154(1) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003) or a fine, or both;
in Scotland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months or a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum, or both;
in Northern Ireland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum, or both;

P3para.Text: on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 7 years or a fine, or both.

P2para.Text: This section has effect for the interpretation of section 27.
“Bank” means a UK institution which has permission under Part 4A of FSMA 2000 to carry on the regulated activity of accepting deposits.
But “bank” does not include—

P3para.Text: an insurer, or
a credit union.

P2para.Text: In subsections (2) and (3)—

P3para.Text: “UK institution” means an institution which is incorporated in, or formed under the law of any part of, the United Kingdom;
“insurer” means an institution which is authorised under FSMA 2000 to carry on the regulated activity of effecting or carrying out contracts of insurance as principal;
“credit union” means a credit union as defined by section 31 of the Credit Unions Act 1979 or a credit union as defined by Article 2(2) of the Credit Unions (Northern Ireland) Order 1985.

P2para.Text: Subsections (2) and (4)(b) are to be read in accordance with section 22 of FSMA 2000, taken with Schedule 2 to that Act and any order under that section.

A person is a “senior manager” in relation to a bank if, under an arrangement entered into by the bank, or by a contractor of the bank, in relation to the carrying on by the bank of a regulated activity, the person performs a function that is designated as a senior management function—

P3para.Text: by the FCA under subsection (6B) of section 59 of FSMA 2000 (approval for particular arrangements), or
by the PRA under subsection (6C) of that section.

P2para.Text: A bank (“B”) is to be regarded as failing where—

P3para.Text: B enters insolvency,
any of the stabilisation options in Part 1 of the Banking Act 2009 is achieved in relation to B, or
B is taken for the purposes of the Financial Services Compensation Scheme to be unable, or likely to be unable, to satisfy claims against B.

P2para.Text: In subsection (7)(a) “insolvency” includes—

P3para.Text: bankruptcy,
liquidation,
bank insolvency,
administration,
bank administration,
receivership,
a composition between B and B’s creditors, and
a scheme of arrangement of B’s affairs.

P2para.Text: In this section “an offence” means an offence under section 27.
Proceedings for an offence may be instituted in England and Wales only—

P3para.Text: by the FCA, the PRA or the Secretary of State, or
by or with the consent of the Director of Public Prosecutions.

P2para.Text: Proceedings for an offence may be instituted in Northern Ireland only—

P3para.Text: by the FCA, the PRA or the Secretary of State, or
by or with the consent of the Director of Public Prosecutions for Northern Ireland.

P2para.Text: In exercising its power to institute proceedings for an offence, the FCA or the PRA must comply with any conditions or restrictions imposed in writing by the Treasury.
Conditions or restrictions may be imposed under subsection (4) in relation to—

P3para.Text: proceedings generally, or
such proceedings, or categories of proceedings, as the Treasury may direct.

P2para.Text: This Part contains provision for the establishment of a new body (the “Payment Systems Regulator”) to exercise functions in relation to payment systems.
Section 31 provides for the establishment of the Payment Systems Regulator.
Sections 32 and 33 contain definitions of “payment system” and related terms.
Sections 34 to 38 make provision about designating a payment system as a regulated payment system.
Sections 39 to 43 contain provision about the general duties of the Payment Systems Regulator under this Part.
Sections 44 to 57 confer various regulatory and competition functions on the Payment Systems Regulator.
Sections 58 to 60 contain provision about the making of complaints to the Payment Systems Regulator.
Sections 61 to 70 contain provision about enforcement and appeals.
Sections 71 to 82 contain supplementary powers.
Sections 83 to 87 contain provision about the Payment Systems Regulator’s relationship with other regulators.
Sections 88 to 92 contain provision about consultation, accountability and oversight.
Sections 93 to 95 contain miscellaneous and supplemental provision.
The FCA must establish a body corporate to exercise the functions conferred on the body by or under this Part.
The body established under subsection (1) is referred to in this Part as the Payment Systems Regulator.
The FCA must take such steps as are necessary to ensure that the Payment Systems Regulator is, at all times, capable of exercising the functions referred to in subsection (1).
In complying with the duty imposed by subsection (3) the FCA may, in particular—

P3para.Text: provide staff to the Payment Systems Regulator, and
provide services to the Payment Systems Regulator which the FCA considers would facilitate the exercise of any of those functions.

P2para.Text: Schedule 4 (which contains further provision about the Payment Systems Regulator) has effect.

In this Part “payment system” means a system which is operated by one or more persons in the course of business for the purpose of enabling persons to make transfers of funds, and includes a system which is designed to facilitate the transfer of funds using another payment system.
But “payment system” does not include—

P3para.Text: any arrangements for the physical movement of cash;
a system which does not make any provision for the transfer of funds by payers, or to recipients, in the United Kingdom;
a securities settlement system operated by a person approved under regulations under section 785 of the Companies Act 2006 (provision enabling procedures for evidencing and transferring title);
a system operated by a recognised clearing house;
any other system whose primary purpose is not that of enabling persons to transfer funds.

P2para.Text: In this section—

Para.Text: “recognised clearing house” has the meaning given by section 285(1) of FSMA 2000;

“securities settlement system” means a computer-based system, and procedures, which enable title to units of a security to be evidenced and transferred without a written instrument, and which facilitate supplementary and incidental matters.

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by order amend this section so as to—

P3para.Text: add descriptions of systems or arrangements that are not to be regarded as payment systems, or
vary or remove any such description.

P2para.Text: This section applies for the purposes of this Part.
The following persons are “participants” in a payment system—

P3para.Text: the operator of the payment system (see subsection (3));
any infrastructure provider (see subsection (4));
any payment service provider (see subsection (5)).

P2para.Text: (But see also subsection (8).)

“Operator”, in relation to a payment system, means any person with responsibility under the system for managing or operating it; and any reference to the operation of a payment system includes a reference to its management.
“Infrastructure provider”, in relation to a payment system, means any person who provides or controls any part of the infrastructure used for the purposes of operating the payment system.

“Payment service provider”, in relation to a payment system, means any person who provides services to persons who are not participants in the system for the purposes of enabling the transfer of funds using the payment system.

A payment service provider has “direct access” to a payment system if the payment service provider is able to provide services for the purposes of enabling the transfer of funds using the payment system as a result of arrangements made between the payment service provider and the operator of the payment system.
Any reference to participation in a payment system is to be read in accordance with this section, and in particular—

P3para.Text: in the case of an operator of a payment system, includes a reference to developing the system, and

in the case of a payment service provider with direct access to a payment system, includes a reference to entering into an agreement with a person to enable the person to become a payment service provider in relation to the system.

P2para.Text: The Bank of England is not to be regarded as a participant of any kind in any payment system.

Pblock.Title: Designation as a regulated payment system

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by order (a “designation order”) designate a payment system as a regulated payment system for the purposes of this Part.
A designation order must specify in as much detail as is reasonably practicable the arrangements that constitute the payment system.

The Treasury may make a designation order in respect of a payment system only if they are satisfied that any deficiencies in the design of the system, or any disruption of its operation, would be likely to have serious consequences for those who use, or are likely to use, the services provided by the system.
In considering whether to make a designation order in respect of a payment system, the Treasury must have regard to—

P3para.Text: the number and value of the transactions that the system presently processes or is likely to process in the future,
the nature of the transactions that the system presently processes or is likely to process in the future,
whether those transactions or their equivalent could be handled by other payment systems, and
the relationship between the system and other payment systems.

P2para.Text: Before making a designation order in respect of a payment system the Treasury must—

P3para.Text: consult the Payment Systems Regulator and, if the system is a recognised inter-bank payment system, the Bank of England,
notify the operator of the system, and
consider any representations made.

P2para.Text: In considering whether to make a designation order in respect of a payment system, the Treasury may rely on information provided by—

P3para.Text: the Bank of England,
the FCA,
the PRA, or
the Payment Systems Regulator.

P2para.Text: The Treasury may amend a designation order.
Before amending a designation order made in respect of a payment system, the Treasury must—

P3para.Text: consult the Payment Systems Regulator and, if the payment system is a recognised inter-bank payment system, the Bank of England,
notify the operator of the payment system, and
consider any representations made.

P2para.Text: The Treasury must consider any request by the operator of a regulated payment system for the amendment of its designation order.
The Treasury may revoke a designation order.
The Treasury must revoke a designation order if they are not satisfied that the criteria in section 35 are met in respect of the payment system to which the order relates.
Before revoking a designation order made in respect of a payment system, the Treasury must—

P3para.Text: consult the Payment Systems Regulator and, if the payment system is a recognised inter-bank payment system, the Bank of England,
notify the operator of the payment system, and
consider any representations made.

P2para.Text: The Treasury must consider any request by the operator of a regulated payment system for the revocation of its designation order.

P1group.Title: Regulator’s general duties in relation to payment systems

P2para.Text: In discharging its general functions relating to payment systems the Payment Systems Regulator must, so far as is reasonably possible, act in a way which advances one or more of its payment systems objectives.
The payment systems objectives of the Payment Systems Regulator are—

P3para.Text: the competition objective (see section 40),
the innovation objective (see section 41), and
the service-user objective (see section 42).

P2para.Text: In discharging its general functions relating to payment systems the Payment Systems Regulator must have regard to—

P3para.Text: the importance of maintaining the stability of, and confidence in, the UK financial system,
the importance of payment systems in relation to the performance of functions by the Bank of England in its capacity as a monetary authority, and
the regulatory principles in section 43.

P2para.Text: The general functions of the Payment Systems Regulator relating to payment systems are—

P3para.Text: its function of giving general directions under section 44 (considered as a whole),
its functions in relation to the giving of general guidance under section 81 (considered as a whole), and
its function of determining the general policy and principles by reference to which it performs particular functions.

P2para.Text: The competition objective is to promote effective competition in—

P3para.Text: the market for payment systems, and
the markets for services provided by payment systems,

P2para.Text: in the interests of those who use, or are likely to use, services provided by payment systems.
The reference in subsection (1) to promoting effective competition includes, in particular, promoting effective competition—

P3para.Text: between different operators of payment systems,
between different payment service providers, and
between different infrastructure providers.

P2para.Text: The matters to which the Payment Systems Regulator may have regard in considering the effectiveness of competition in a market mentioned in subsection (1) include—

P3para.Text: the needs of different persons who use, or may use, services provided by payment systems;
the ease with which persons who may wish to use those services can do so;
the ease with which persons who obtain those services can change the person from whom they obtain them;
the needs of different payment service providers or persons who wish to become payment service providers;
the ease with which payment service providers, or persons who wish to become payment service providers, can provide services using payment systems;
the ease with which payment service providers can change the payment system they use to provide their services;
the needs of different infrastructure providers or persons who wish to become infrastructure providers;
the ease with which infrastructure providers, or persons who wish to become infrastructure providers, can provide infrastructure for the purposes of operating payment systems;
the needs of different operators of payment systems;
the ease with which operators of payment systems can change the infrastructure used to operate the payment systems;
the level and structure of fees, charges or other costs associated with participation in payment systems;
the ease with which new entrants can enter the market;
how far competition is contributing to the development of efficient and effective infrastructure for the purposes of operating payment systems;
how far competition is encouraging innovation.

P2para.Text: The innovation objective is to promote the development of, and innovation in, payment systems in the interests of those who use, or are likely to use, services provided by payment systems, with a view to improving the quality, efficiency and economy of payment systems.

The reference in subsection (1) to promoting the development of, and innovation in, payment systems includes, in particular, a reference to promoting the development of, and innovation in, infrastructure to be used for the purposes of operating payment systems.

P1para.Text: The service-user objective is to ensure that payment systems are operated and developed in a way that takes account of, and promotes, the interests of those who use, or are likely to use, services provided by payment systems.
The regulatory principles referred to in section 39(3)(c) are as follows—

P3para.Text: the need to use the resources of the Payment Systems Regulator in the most efficient and economic way;

the principle that a burden or restriction which is imposed on a person, or on the carrying on of an activity, should be proportionate to the benefits, considered in general terms, which are expected to result from the imposition of that burden or restriction;
the desirability of sustainable growth in the economy of the United Kingdom in the medium or long term;
the general principle that those who use services provided by payment systems should take responsibility for their decisions;

the responsibilities of the senior management of persons subject to requirements imposed by or under this Part, including those affecting persons who use services provided by payment systems, in relation to compliance with those requirements;

the desirability where appropriate of the Payment Systems Regulator exercising its functions in a way that recognises differences in the nature of, and objectives of, businesses carried on by different persons subject to requirements imposed by or under this Part;

the desirability in appropriate cases of the Payment Systems Regulator publishing information relating to persons on whom requirements are imposed by or under this Part, or requiring such persons to publish
information, as a means of contributing to the advancement by the Payment Systems Regulator of its payment systems objectives;
the principle that the Payment Systems Regulator should exercise its functions as transparently as possible.

P2para.Text: The Payment Systems Regulator may give directions in writing to participants in regulated payment systems.
A direction given to a participant in a regulated payment system may—

P3para.Text: require or prohibit the taking of specified action in relation to the system;
set standards to be met in relation to the system.

P2para.Text: A direction under this section may apply—

P3para.Text: generally,
in relation to all operators, all infrastructure providers or all payment service providers, or
in relation to specified persons or persons of a specified description.

P2para.Text: The Payment Systems Regulator must publish any direction given under this section that applies as mentioned in subsection (3)(a) or (b).
A direction under this section that applies as mentioned in subsection (3)(a) is referred to in this Part as a “general direction”.
The Payment Systems Regulator may require the operator of a regulated payment system—

P3para.Text: to establish rules for the operation of the system;
to change the rules in a specified way or so as to achieve a specified purpose;
to notify the Payment Systems Regulator of any proposed change to the rules;
not to change the rules without the approval of the Payment Systems Regulator.

P2para.Text: A requirement under subsection (1)(c) or (d) may be general or specific.

P1group.Title: Power to require granting of access to payment systems

P2para.Text: This section applies where a person (“the applicant”) applies for an order under this section.
The Payment Systems Regulator may by order require the operator of a regulated payment system to enable the applicant to become a payment service provider in relation to the system.
The Payment Systems Regulator may by order require any payment service provider with direct access to a regulated payment system to enter into an
agreement with the applicant to enable the applicant to become a payment service provider in relation to the system.
An order under this section may provide for the applicant to become a payment service provider in relation to a payment system—

P3para.Text: for a period specified in the order;
on terms and conditions specified in the order.

P1group.Title: Variation of agreements relating to payment systems

P2para.Text: This section applies to the following agreements—

P3para.Text: any agreement made between the operator of a regulated payment system and a payment service provider;

any agreement made between a payment service provider with direct access to a regulated payment system and another person for the purpose of enabling that other person to become a payment service provider in relation to the system;
any agreement concerning fees or charges payable in connection with—

P4para.Text: participation in a regulated payment system, or
the use of services provided by a regulated payment system.

P2para.Text: The Payment Systems Regulator may, on the application of a party to an agreement to which this section applies, vary the agreement by—

P3para.Text: varying any of the fees or charges payable under the agreement, or
in the case of an agreement within subsection (1)(a) or (b), varying any other terms and conditions relating to the payment service provider’s participation in the payment system.

P2para.Text: In the case of an agreement within subsection (1)(b), the reference in subsection (2)(b) to the payment service provider is to the payment service provider which does not have direct access to the payment system.
The power under this section to vary any fee or charge includes power to specify a maximum fee or charge.
If the Payment Systems Regulator varies an agreement under this section, the agreement has effect subject to the variation.

P1group.Title: Power to require disposal of interest in payment system

P2para.Text: The Payment Systems Regulator may require a person who has an interest in the operator of a regulated payment system to dispose of all or part of that interest.

The power conferred by subsection (1) may be exercised only if the Payment Systems Regulator is satisfied that, if the power is not exercised, there is likely to be a restriction or distortion of competition in—

P3para.Text: the market for payment systems, or
a market for services provided by payment systems.

P2para.Text: The Payment Systems Regulator may not exercise the power conferred by subsection (1) without the consent of the Treasury.
If the Payment Systems Regulator decides to exercise the power conferred by subsection (1) in relation to a person who has an interest in the operator of a regulated payment system—

P3para.Text: the Payment Systems Regulator must notify the relevant competition authorities (see subsection (5)), and
the relevant competition authorities may not take any action in relation to the person that would require the person to dispose of all or part of that interest.

P2para.Text: The relevant competition authorities are—

P3para.Text: the Secretary of State,
the Competition and Markets Authority, and
the FCA.

P1group.Title: The Regulator’s functions under Part 4 of the Enterprise Act 2002

P2para.Text: The functions to which this subsection applies (“the concurrent functions”) are to be concurrent functions of the Payment Systems Regulator and the Competition and Markets Authority (“the CMA”).
Subsection (1) applies to the functions of the CMA under Part 4 of the Enterprise Act 2002 (market investigations), so far as those functions—

P3para.Text: are exercisable by the CMA Board (within the meaning of Schedule 4 to the Enterprise and Regulatory Reform Act 2013), and
relate to participation in payment systems.

P2para.Text: But subsection (1) does not apply to functions under the following sections of the Enterprise Act 2002—

P3para.Text: section 166 (duty to maintain register of undertakings and orders);
section 171 (duty to publish guidance).

P2para.Text: So far as is necessary for the purposes of, or in connection with, subsections (1) and (2)—

P3para.Text: references in Part 4 of the Enterprise Act 2002 to the CMA (including references in provisions of that Act applied by that Part) are to be read as including references to the Payment Systems Regulator,
references in that Part to section 5 of that Act are to be read as including references to section 54 of this Act, and

references in that Part to consumers are to be read as including references to any person who uses, or is likely to use, services provided by payment systems in the course of a business carried on by the person.

P2para.Text: But subsection (4) does not apply—

P3para.Text: in relation to section 166 or 171 of that Act, or
where the context otherwise requires.

P2para.Text: Section 130A of the Enterprise Act 2002 is to have effect in relation to the Payment Systems Regulator by virtue of subsections (1) and (2) as if—

P3para.Text: in subsection (2)(a) of that section, the reference to the acquisition or supply of goods or services of one or more than one description in the United Kingdom were a reference to the participation in payment systems used to provide services in the United Kingdom, and

in subsection (2)(b) of that section, the reference to the extent to which steps can and should be taken were a reference to the extent to which steps that might include steps under Part 4 of that Act can and should be taken.

P1group.Title: Restrictions on exercise of functions under Part 4 of the Enterprise Act 2002

P2para.Text: Before the CMA or the Payment Systems Regulator first exercises any of the concurrent functions in relation to any matter, it must consult the other.

Neither the CMA nor the Payment Systems Regulator may exercise any of the concurrent functions in relation to any matter if any of those functions have been exercised in relation to that matter by the other.
In subsections (1) and (2) “the concurrent functions” has the same meaning as in section 49.
Before the FCA or the Payment Systems Regulator first exercises any of the concurrent functions in relation to any matter, it must consult the other.

Neither the FCA nor the Payment Systems Regulator may exercise any of the concurrent functions in relation to any matter if any of those functions have been exercised in relation to that matter by the other.
In subsections (4) and (5) “the concurrent functions”—

P3para.Text: in relation to the Payment Systems Regulator, has the same meaning as in section 49, and
in relation to the FCA, means the functions which by virtue of section 234J of FSMA 2000 are concurrent functions of the FCA and the CMA.

P2para.Text: In this section “the CMA” means the Competition and Markets Authority.

P1group.Title: The Regulator’s functions under the Competition Act 1998

P2para.Text: The functions to which this subsection applies are to be concurrent functions of the Payment Systems Regulator and the Competition and Markets Authority (“the CMA”).

Subsection (1) applies to the functions of the CMA under the provisions of Part 1 of the Competition Act 1998, so far as relating to any of the following that relate to participation in payment systems—

P3para.Text: agreements, decisions or concerted practices of the kind mentioned in section 2(1) of that Act,
conduct of the kind mentioned in section 18(1) of that Act,
agreements, decisions or concerted practices of the kind mentioned in Article 101(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and
conduct which amounts to abuse of the kind mentioned in Article 102 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

P2para.Text: But subsection (1) does not apply to functions under the following sections of that Act—

P3para.Text: section 31D(1) to (6) (duty to publish guidance);
section 38(1) to (6) (duty to publish guidance about penalties);
section 40B(1) to (4) (duty to publish statement of policy on penalties);
section 51 (rules).

P2para.Text: So far as necessary for the purposes of, or in connection with, the provisions of subsections (1) and (2), references to the CMA in Part 1 of the Competition Act 1998 are to be read as including references to the Payment Systems Regulator.
But subsection (4) does not apply—

P3para.Text: in relation to sections 31D(1) to (6), 38(1) to (6), 40B(1) to (4), 51, 52(6) and (8) and 54 of that Act, or
where the context otherwise requires.

P1group.Title: Duty to consider exercise of powers under Competition Act 1998

P2para.Text: Before exercising any power within subsection (2), the Payment Systems Regulator must consider whether it would be more appropriate to proceed under the Competition Act 1998.
The powers referred to in subsection (1) are—

P3para.Text: its power to give a direction under section 44 (apart from the power to give a general direction);
its power to impose a requirement under section 45 (apart from the power to impose a requirement on all operators of regulated payment systems);
its powers under sections 46, 47 and 48.

P2para.Text: The Payment Systems Regulator must not exercise the power if it considers that it would be more appropriate to proceed under the Competition Act 1998.

P1group.Title: Provision of information and assistance to a CMA group

P2para.Text: For the purpose of assisting a CMA group in carrying out a relevant investigation, the Payment Systems Regulator must give the CMA group—

P3para.Text: any relevant information which it has in its possession, and
any other assistance which the CMA group may reasonably require in relation to any matters falling within the scope of the investigation.

P2para.Text: A “relevant investigation” is an investigation carried out on a reference made by the Payment Systems Regulator under section 131 of the Enterprise Act 2002 by virtue of section 49.
“Relevant information”, in relation to a relevant investigation, is information—

P3para.Text: which relates to matters falling within the scope of the investigation, and
which—

P4para.Text: is requested by the CMA group for the purpose of the investigation, or
in the opinion of the Payment Systems Regulator, it would be appropriate to give to the CMA group for that purpose.

P2para.Text: A CMA group, in carrying out a relevant investigation, must take into account any information given to it under this section.
In this section “CMA group” has the same meaning as in Schedule 4 to the Enterprise and Regulatory Reform Act 2013.

P1group.Title: Function of keeping markets under review

P2para.Text: For the purpose of the functions conferred on it by sections 48 to 53 the Payment Systems Regulator is to have the function of keeping under review—

P3para.Text: the market for payment systems, and
the markets for services provided by payment systems.

P2para.Text: The function conferred by subsection (1) is to be carried out with a view to (among other things) ensuring that the Payment Systems Regulator has sufficient information to take informed decisions and to carry out its other functions effectively.

Section 39 (the Payment Systems Regulator’s general duties) does not apply in relation to anything done by the Payment Systems Regulator in the carrying out of its functions by virtue of sections 49 to 53.

But in the carrying out of any functions by virtue of sections 49 to 53, the Payment Systems Regulator may have regard to any of the matters in respect of which a duty is imposed by section 39 if it is a matter to which the Competition and Markets Authority is entitled to have regard in the carrying out of those functions.

If any question arises as to whether, by virtue of section 49 or 51, any functions fall to be, or are capable of being, carried out by the Payment Systems Regulator in relation to any particular case, that question is to be referred to, and determined by, the Treasury.

No objection is to be taken to anything done under the Competition Act 1998 or Part 4 of the Enterprise Act 2002 by or in relation to the Payment Systems Regulator on the ground that it should have been done by or in relation to the Competition and Markets Authority.

P1group.Title: Amendments relating to Regulator’s competition powers

P2para.Text: In section 9E of the Company Directors Disqualification Act 1986 (interpretation of sections 9A to 9D), in subsection (2), after paragraph (f) insert—

P3para.Text: the Payment Systems Regulator established under section 31 of the Financial Services (Banking Reform) Act 2013.

P2para.Text: In section 54 of the Competition Act 1998 (regulators), in subsection (1), omit the “and” at the end of paragraph (g) and after paragraph (h) insert—

P3para.Text: the Payment Systems Regulator established under section 31 of the Financial Services (Banking Reform) Act 2013.

P2para.Text: In section 136 of the Enterprise Act 2002 (investigations and reports on market investigation references)—

P3para.Text: in subsection (7), at the end insert—
in relation to the Payment Systems Regulator, section 49 of the Financial Services (Banking Reform) Act 2013.
in subsection (8), for “or Monitor” substitute “, Monitor or the Payment Systems Regulator.”;
at the end insert—

P2para.Text: In this section “the Payment Systems Regulator” means the body established under section 31 of the Financial Services (Banking Reform) Act 2013.
In section 52(4) of the Enterprise and Regulatory Reform Act 2013 (power to remove concurrent competition functions of sectoral regulators), after paragraph (f) insert—

P3para.Text: the Payment Systems Regulator established under section 31 of the Financial Services (Banking Reform) Act 2013.

P2para.Text: In Schedule 4 to the Enterprise and Regulatory Reform Act 2013 (the Competition and Markets Authority), in paragraph 16 (concurrency report), at the end of sub-paragraph (7) insert—

P3para.Text: the Payment Systems Regulator established under section 31 of the Financial Services (Banking Reform) Act 2013.

P2para.Text: A designated representative body may make a complaint to the Payment Systems Regulator that a feature, or combination of features, of a market in the United Kingdom for services provided by payment systems is, or appears to be, significantly damaging the interests of those who use, or are likely to use, those services (“service-users”).
“Designated representative body” means a body designated by the Treasury by order.
The Treasury—

P3para.Text: may designate a body only if it appears to them to represent the interests of service-users of any description, and
must publish in such manner as they think fit (and may from time to time vary) criteria to be applied by them in determining whether to make or revoke a designation.

P2para.Text: The reference in subsection (1) to a feature of a market in the United Kingdom for services provided by payment systems is a reference to—

P3para.Text: the structure of the market concerned or any aspect of that structure,
any conduct (whether or not in the market concerned) of one or more than one person who supplies or acquires services in the market concerned, or
any conduct relating to the market concerned of customers of any person who supplies or acquires services,

P2para.Text: and “conduct” includes any failure to act (whether or not intentional) and any other unintentional conduct.
In this section “market in the United Kingdom” includes a market which operates only in a part of the United Kingdom.
In section 234C of FSMA 2000 (complaints by consumer bodies), after
subsection (1) insert—

But a complaint may not be made to the FCA under this section if it is a complaint which could be made to the Payment Systems Regulator by a designated representative body under section 58 of the Financial Services (Banking Reform) Act 2013 (complaints by representative bodies).
“Designated representative body” and “the Payment Systems Regulator” have the same meaning in this subsection as they have in that section.
“Designated representative body” and “the Payment Systems Regulator” have the same meaning in this subsection as they have in that section.

The Payment Systems Regulator must within 90 days after the day on which it receives a complaint under section 58 publish a response stating how it proposes to deal with the complaint, and in particular—

P3para.Text: whether it has decided to take any action, or to take no action, and
if it has decided to take action, what action it proposes to take.

P2para.Text: The response must—

P3para.Text: include a copy of the complaint, and
state the Payment Systems Regulator’s reasons for its proposals.

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by order amend subsection (1) by substituting any period for the period for the time being specified there.
The guidance given by the Payment Systems Regulator under section 81—

P3para.Text: must include guidance about the presentation of a reasoned case for a complaint under section 58, and
may include guidance about any other matters that appear to the Payment Systems Regulator to be appropriate for the purposes of that section.

P2para.Text: Guidance given in accordance with subsection (1) is to be treated as general guidance for the purposes of this Part.

P1para.Text: In this Part “compliance failure” means a failure by a participant in a regulated payment system to—

P3para.Text: comply with a direction given under section 44, or
comply with a requirement imposed under section 45 or 46.

P2para.Text: The Payment Systems Regulator may publish details of a compliance failure by a participant in a regulated payment system.
The Payment Systems Regulator may publish details of a sanction imposed under section 63.
The Payment Systems Regulator may require a participant in a regulated payment system to pay a penalty in respect of a compliance failure.
A penalty—

P3para.Text: must be paid to the Payment Systems Regulator, and
may be enforced by the Payment Systems Regulator as a debt.

P2para.Text: The Payment Systems Regulator must prepare a statement of the principles which it will apply in determining—

P3para.Text: whether to impose a penalty, and
the amount of a penalty.

P2para.Text: The Payment Systems Regulator must—

P3para.Text: publish the statement on its website,
send a copy to the Treasury,
review the statement from time to time and revise it if necessary (and paragraphs (a) and (b) apply to a revision), and
in applying the statement to a compliance failure, apply the version in force when the compliance failure occurred.

P2para.Text: Before imposing a sanction on any person the Payment Systems Regulator must—

P3para.Text: give the person a notice in writing (a “warning notice”),
give the person at least 21 days to make representations,
consider any representations made, and
as soon as is reasonably practicable, give the person a notice in writing stating whether or not it intends to impose the sanction.

P2para.Text: In subsection (1) any reference to imposing a sanction is a reference to—

P3para.Text: publishing details under section 62(1), or
requiring the payment of a penalty under section 63.

P2para.Text: If, on the application of the Payment Systems Regulator, the court is satisfied—

P3para.Text: that there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a compliance failure, or
that there has been a compliance failure and there is a reasonable likelihood that it will continue or be repeated,

P2para.Text: the court may make an order restraining the conduct constituting the failure.
If, on the application of the Payment Systems Regulator, the court is satisfied—

P3para.Text: that there has been a compliance failure by a participant in a regulated payment system, and
that there are steps which could be taken for remedying the failure,

P2para.Text: the court may make an order requiring the participant, and anyone else who appears to have been knowingly concerned in the failure, to take such steps as the court may direct to remedy it.
If, on the application of the Payment Systems Regulator, the court is satisfied—

P3para.Text: that there may have been a compliance failure by a participant in a regulated payment system, or
that a person may have been knowingly concerned in a compliance failure,

P2para.Text: the court may make an order restraining the participant or the person (as the case may be) from dealing with any assets which it is satisfied the participant or person is reasonably likely to deal with.
The jurisdiction conferred by this section is exercisable—

P3para.Text: in England and Wales and Northern Ireland, by the High Court, and
in Scotland, by the Court of Session.

P2para.Text: In this section—

P3para.Text: references to an order restraining anything are, in Scotland, to be read as references to an interdict prohibiting that thing,
references to remedying a failure include mitigating its effect, and
references to dealing with assets include disposing of them.

P2para.Text: A person who is affected by any of the following decisions of the Payment Systems Regulator may appeal against the decision—

P3para.Text: a decision to give a direction under section 44 (other than a general direction),
a decision to impose a requirement under section 45 (other than a requirement imposed on all operators of regulated payment systems),
a decision to exercise its power under section 46, 47 or 48,
a decision to impose a sanction.

P2para.Text: In subsection (1) the reference to imposing a sanction is a reference to—

P3para.Text: publishing details under section 62(1), or
requiring the payment of a penalty under section 63.

P2para.Text: If the decision is a CAT-appealable decision, the appeal must be made to the Competition Appeal Tribunal in accordance with section 67.
A “CAT-appealable decision” means—

P3para.Text: a decision to give a direction under section 44,
a decision to impose a requirement under section 45, or
a decision to publish details under section 62(1).

P2para.Text: If the decision is a decision to impose a penalty on the person under section 63, the appeal must be made to the Competition Appeal Tribunal in accordance with section 68.
If the decision is a CMA-appealable decision, the appeal must be made to the Competition and Markets Authority (“the CMA”) in accordance with section 69.
A “CMA-appealable decision” means—

P3para.Text: a decision to impose a requirement under section 46,
a decision to vary an agreement under section 47, or
a decision to impose a requirement under section 48.

P2para.Text: The permission of the CMA is required for an appeal to be made in accordance with section 69.
The CMA may refuse permission for an appeal only if—

P3para.Text: the appeal is made for reasons that are trivial or vexatious, or
the appeal has no reasonable prospect of success.

P2para.Text: This section applies where a person is appealing to the Competition Appeal Tribunal (“the Tribunal”) against a CAT-appealable decision.
The means of making an appeal is by sending the Tribunal a notice of appeal in accordance with Tribunal rules.
The notice of appeal must be sent within the period specified, in relation to the decision appealed against, in those rules.
In determining an appeal made in accordance with this section, the Tribunal must apply the same principles as would be applied by a court on an application for judicial review.
The Tribunal must either—

P3para.Text: dismiss the appeal, or
quash the whole or part of the decision to which the appeal relates.

P2para.Text: If the Tribunal quashes the whole or part of a decision, it may refer the matter back to the Payment Systems Regulator with a direction to reconsider and make a new decision in accordance with its ruling.
The Tribunal may not direct the Payment Systems Regulator to take any action which it would not otherwise have the power to take in relation to the decision.

The effect of a decision to publish details under section 62(1) is suspended by the making of an appeal against the decision (and the details may not be published until the appeal has been determined).
The effect of any other CAT-appealable decision is not suspended by the making of an appeal against the decision.
In this section and section 68 “Tribunal rules” means rules under section 15 of the Enterprise Act 2002.
This section applies where a person is appealing to the Competition Appeal Tribunal (“the Tribunal”) against a decision to impose a penalty under section 63.
The person may appeal against—

P3para.Text: the imposition of the penalty,
the amount of the penalty, or
any date by which the penalty, or any part of it, is required to be paid.

P2para.Text: The means of making an appeal is by sending the Tribunal a notice of appeal in accordance with Tribunal rules.
The notice of appeal must be sent within the period specified, in relation to the decision appealed against, in those rules.
The Tribunal may do any of the following—

P3para.Text: uphold the penalty;
set aside the penalty;
substitute for the penalty a penalty of an amount decided by the Tribunal;
vary any date by which the penalty, or any part of it, is required to be paid.

P2para.Text: If an appeal is made in accordance with this section, the penalty is not required to be paid until the appeal has been determined.
Subsections (2), (5) and (6) do not restrict the power to make Tribunal rules; and those subsections are subject to Tribunal rules.
Except as provided by this section, the validity of the penalty may not be questioned by any legal proceedings whatever.

In the case of an appeal made in accordance with this section, a decision of the Tribunal has the same effect as, and may be enforced in the same manner as, a decision of the Payment Systems Regulator.

P1group.Title: Appeals to Competition and Markets Authority

P2para.Text: This section applies where a person is appealing to the Competition and Markets Authority (“the CMA”) against a CMA-appealable decision.

In determining the appeal the CMA must have regard, to the same extent as is required of the Payment Systems Regulator, to the matters to which the Payment Systems Regulator must have regard in discharging its functions under this Part.
In determining the appeal the CMA—

P3para.Text: may have regard to any matter to which the Payment Systems Regulator was not able to have regard in relation to the decision, but

must not, in the exercise of that power, have regard to any matter to which the Payment Systems Regulator would not have been entitled to have regard in reaching its decision had it had the opportunity of doing so.

P2para.Text: The CMA must either—

P3para.Text: dismiss the appeal, or
quash the whole or part of the decision to which the appeal relates.

P2para.Text: The CMA may act as mentioned in subsection (4)(b) only to the extent that it is satisfied that the decision was wrong on one or more of the following grounds—

P3para.Text: that the Payment Systems Regulator failed properly to have regard to any matter mentioned in subsection (2);
that the Payment Systems Regulator failed to give the appropriate weight to any matter mentioned in subsection (2);
that the decision was based, wholly or partly, on an error of fact;
that the decision was wrong in law.

P2para.Text: If the CMA quashes the whole or part of a decision, it may either—

P3para.Text: refer the matter back to the Payment Systems Regulator with a direction to reconsider and make a new decision in accordance with its ruling, or
substitute its own decision for that of the Payment Systems Regulator.

P2para.Text: The CMA may not direct the Payment Systems Regulator to take any action which it would not otherwise have the power to take in relation to the decision.
Schedule 5 contains further provision about the making of appeals in accordance with this section.

P1group.Title: Enforcement of requirement to dispose of interest in payment system

P2para.Text: A requirement imposed under section 48 is enforceable by civil proceedings brought by the Payment Systems Regulator for an injunction or for interdict or for any other appropriate relief or remedy.
Civil proceedings may not be brought to enforce a requirement imposed under that section unless—

P3para.Text: the time for bringing an appeal against the decision to impose the requirement has expired and no appeal has been brought within that time, or
the person on whom the requirement was imposed has within that time brought such an appeal and the appeal has been dismissed or withdrawn.

P1group.Title: Power to obtain information or documents

P2para.Text: The Payment Systems Regulator may by notice in writing require a person to provide information or documents—

P3para.Text: which the Payment Systems Regulator thinks will help the Treasury in determining whether to make a designation order, or
which the Payment Systems Regulator otherwise requires in connection with its functions under this Part.

P2para.Text: In particular, a notice under subsection (1) may require a participant in a regulated payment system to notify the Payment Systems Regulator if events of a specified kind occur.
A notice under subsection (1) may require information or documents to be provided—

P3para.Text: in a specified form or manner;
at a specified time;
in respect of a specified period.

P2para.Text: The Payment Systems Regulator may disclose information obtained by virtue of this section to—

P3para.Text: the Treasury;
the Bank of England;
the FCA;
the PRA;
the Office of Communications;

an authority in a country or territory outside the United Kingdom that exercises functions similar to those of the Treasury, the Bank of England, the FCA, the PRA or the Payment Systems Regulator in relation to payment systems;
the European Commission;
the European Central Bank;
the Bank for International Settlements.

P2para.Text: Subsection (4)—

P3para.Text: overrides any requirement to keep information in confidence, and
is without prejudice to any other power to disclose information.

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by regulations permit the disclosure of information obtained by virtue of this section to a specified person.
The Payment Systems Regulator may publish information obtained by virtue of this section.
The Treasury may make regulations about the manner and extent of publication under subsection (7).
In subsection (4)(f) the reference to payment systems is to be read as if subsection (2)(b) of section 32 were omitted.
The Payment Systems Regulator may—

P3para.Text: require a person who is a participant in a regulated payment system (“the relevant participant”) to provide the Payment Systems Regulator with a report on any matter relating to the system (“the matter concerned”), or
appoint a person to provide the Payment Systems Regulator with a report on the matter concerned.

P2para.Text: The power conferred by subsection (1)(a) is exercisable by giving the relevant participant a notice in writing.
When acting under subsection (1)(a), the Payment Systems Regulator may require the report to be in a form specified in the notice.
The Payment Systems Regulator must give written notice of an appointment under subsection (1)(b) to the relevant participant.
A person appointed to make a report under this section—

P3para.Text: must be a person appearing to the Payment Systems Regulator to have the skills necessary to make a report on the matter concerned, and
where the appointment is to be made by the relevant participant, must be a person nominated or approved by the Payment Systems Regulator.

P2para.Text: It is the duty of—

P3para.Text: the relevant participant, and
any person who is providing (or who has at any time provided) services to the relevant participant in relation to the matter concerned,

P2para.Text: to give the person appointed to prepare a report all such assistance as the appointed person may reasonably require.

The obligation imposed by subsection (6) is enforceable, on the application of the Payment Systems Regulator, by an injunction or, in Scotland, by an order for specific performance under section 45 of the Court of Session Act 1988.
The Payment Systems Regulator may direct the relevant participant to pay any expenses incurred by the Payment Systems Regulator in relation to an appointment under subsection (1)(b).

P1group.Title: Appointment of persons to conduct investigations

P2para.Text: If it considers that it is desirable to do so in order to advance any of its payment systems objectives, the Payment Systems Regulator may appoint one or more competent persons to conduct an investigation on its behalf into the nature, conduct or state of the business of any participant in a regulated payment system.

If it appears to the Payment Systems Regulator that there are circumstances suggesting that there may have been a compliance failure, the Payment Systems Regulator may appoint one or more competent persons to conduct an investigation on its behalf.
This section applies if the Payment Systems Regulator appoints one or more competent persons (“investigators”) under section 73 to conduct an investigation on its behalf.
The Payment Systems Regulator must give written notice of the appointment of an investigator to the person who is the subject of the investigation.
Subsections (2) and (9) do not apply if—

P3para.Text: the Payment Systems Regulator believes that the notice required by subsection (2) or (9) would be likely to result in the investigation being frustrated, or
the investigator is appointed under subsection (2) of section 73.

P2para.Text: A notice under subsection (2) must—

P3para.Text: specify the provision under which the investigator was appointed, and
state the reason for the appointment.

P2para.Text: Nothing prevents the Payment Systems Regulator from appointing as an investigator—

P3para.Text: a member of its staff, or
a member of staff of the FCA.

P2para.Text: An investigator who conducts an investigation must make a report of the investigation to the Payment Systems Regulator.
The Payment Systems Regulator may, by a direction to an investigator, control—

P3para.Text: the scope of the investigation,
the period during which the investigation is to be conducted,
the conduct of the investigation, and
the reporting of the investigation.

P2para.Text: A direction may, in particular—

P3para.Text: confine the investigation to particular matters;
extend the investigation to additional matters;
require the investigator to discontinue the investigation or to take only those steps that are specified in the direction;
require the investigator to make such interim reports as are so specified.

P2para.Text: If there is a change in the scope or conduct of the investigation and, in the opinion of the Payment Systems Regulator, the person who is the subject of the investigation is likely to be significantly prejudiced by not being made aware of it, that person must be given written notice of the change.

P1group.Title: Powers of persons appointed under section 73

P2para.Text: An investigator may require any person within subsection (2)—

P3para.Text: to attend before the investigator at a specified time and place and answer questions, or
otherwise to provide any information which the investigator requires.

P2para.Text: The persons referred to in subsection (1) are—

P3para.Text: the person who is the subject of the investigation (“the person under investigation”);
any person connected with the person under investigation;

in the case of an investigation into whether there has been a compliance failure, any person who in the investigator’s opinion is or may be able to give information which is or may be relevant to the investigation.

P2para.Text: An investigator may also require any person to produce at a specified time and place any specified documents or documents of a specified description.

A requirement under subsection (1) or (3) may be imposed only so far as the investigator concerned reasonably considers the question, provision of information or production of the document to be relevant to the purposes of the investigation.

In the case of an investigation into whether there has been a compliance failure, the investigator may also require any person falling within subsection (2)(c) to give the investigator all assistance in connection with the investigation which the person is reasonably able to give.
For the purposes of this section, a person is connected with the person under investigation (“A”) if the person is or has at any relevant time been—

P3para.Text: a member of A’s group,
a controller of A, or
a partnership of which A is a member.

P2para.Text: In this section—

Para.Text: “controller” has the same meaning as in FSMA 2000 (see section 422 of that Act);
“group” has the same meaning as in FSMA 2000 (see section 421 of that Act);
“investigator” means a person conducting an investigation under section 73;
“specified” means specified in a notice in writing.

P2para.Text: In this section “relevant document” means a document produced in response to a requirement imposed under section 71 or 75.
In a case where—

P3para.Text: the Payment Systems Regulator has power under section 71, or an investigator has power under section 75, to require a person to produce a document, but
it appears that the document is in the possession of another person,

P2para.Text: the power may be exercised in relation to that other person.
Any person to whom a relevant document is produced may—

P3para.Text: take copies or extracts from the document, or
require the person producing the document, or any relevant person (see subsection (4)), to provide an explanation of the document.

P2para.Text: “Relevant person”, in relation to a person who is required to produce a document, means a person who—

P3para.Text: has been or is or is proposed to be a director or controller of that person,
has been or is an auditor of that person,
has been or is an actuary, accountant or lawyer appointed or instructed by that person, or
has been or is an employee of that person.

P2para.Text: A relevant document may be retained for so long as the person to whom it is produced considers that it is necessary to retain it (rather than copies of it) for the purposes for which the document was requested.
If the person to whom a relevant document is produced has reasonable grounds for believing—

P3para.Text: that the document may have to be produced for the purposes of any legal proceedings, and
that it might otherwise be unavailable for those purposes,

P2para.Text: it may be retained until the proceedings are concluded.

If a person who is required under section 71 or 75 to produce a document fails to do so, the Payment Systems Regulator or an investigator may require the person to state, to the best of the person’s knowledge and belief, where the document is.
A lawyer may be required under section 71 or 75 or this section to provide the name and address of a client.

A person may not be required under section 71 or 75 or this section to disclose information or produce a document in respect of which the person owes an obligation of confidence as a result of carrying on the business of banking unless—

P3para.Text: the person is the person under investigation or a member of that person’s group,
the person to whom the obligation of confidence is owed is the person under investigation or a member of that person’s group,
the person to whom the obligation of confidence is owed consents to the disclosure or production, or
the imposing on the person of a requirement with respect to such information or document has been specifically authorised by the Payment Systems Regulator.

P2para.Text: If a person claims a lien on a document, its production under section 71 or 75 does not affect the lien.
In this section—

Para.Text: “controller” has the same meaning as in FSMA 2000 (see section 422 of that Act);
“group” has the same meaning as in FSMA 2000 (see section 421 of that Act);
“investigator” means a person appointed under section 73.

P1group.Title: Admissibility of statements made to investigators

P2para.Text: A statement made to an investigator by a person in compliance with an information requirement is admissible in evidence in any proceedings, so long as it also complies with any requirements governing the admissibility of evidence in the circumstances in question.
But in criminal proceedings in which that person is charged with an offence to which this subsection applies—

P3para.Text: no evidence relating to the statement may be adduced by or on behalf of the prosecution, and
no question relating to the statement may be asked by or on behalf of the prosecution,

P2para.Text: unless evidence relating to the statement is adduced, or a question relating to it is asked, in the proceedings by or on behalf of that person.
Subsection (2) applies to any offence other than—

P3para.Text: an offence under section 80(6);
an offence under section 5 of the Perjury Act 1911 (false statements made otherwise than on oath);
an offence under section 44(2) of the Criminal Law (Consolidation) (Scotland) Act 1995 (false statements made otherwise than on oath);
an offence under Article 10 of the Perjury (Northern Ireland) Order 1979.

P2para.Text: In this section—

Para.Text: “information requirement” means a requirement imposed by an investigator under section 75 or 76;
“investigator” means a person appointed under section 73.

P2para.Text: A justice of the peace may issue a warrant under this section if satisfied on information on oath given by or on behalf of the Payment Systems Regulator or an investigator that there are reasonable grounds for believing that the first or second set of conditions is satisfied.
The first set of conditions is—

P3para.Text: that a person on whom an information requirement has been imposed has failed (wholly or in part) to comply with it, and
that on the premises specified in the warrant—

P4para.Text: there are documents which have been required, or
there is information which has been required.

P2para.Text: In this section “information requirement” means—

P3para.Text: a requirement imposed by the Payment Systems Regulator under section 71 or 76, or
a requirement imposed by an investigator under section 75 or 76.

P2para.Text: The second set of conditions is—

P3para.Text: that the premises specified in the warrant are premises of a participant in a regulated payment system,
that there are on the premises documents or information in relation to which an information requirement could be imposed, and
that if such a requirement were to be imposed—

P4para.Text: it would not be complied with, or
the documents or information to which it related would be removed, tampered with or destroyed.

P2para.Text: A warrant under this section authorises a constable—

P3para.Text: to enter the premises specified in the warrant,

to search the premises and take possession of any documents or information appearing to be documents or information of a kind in respect of which a warrant under this section was issued (“the relevant kind”) or to take, in relation to any such documents or information, any other steps which may appear to be necessary for preserving them or preventing interference with them,
to take copies of, or extracts from, any documents or information appearing to be of the relevant kind,
to require any person on the premises to provide an explanation of any document or information appearing to be of the relevant kind or to state where it may be found, and
to use such force as may be reasonably necessary.

P2para.Text: A warrant under this section may be executed by any constable.
The warrant may authorise persons to accompany any constable who is executing it.
The powers in subsection (5) may be exercised by a person who—

P3para.Text: is authorised by the warrant to accompany a constable, and
exercises those powers in the company of, and under the supervision of, a constable.

P2para.Text: In England and Wales, sections 15(5) to (8) and 16(3) to (12) of the Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984 (execution of search warrants and safeguards) apply to warrants issued under this section.
In Northern Ireland, Articles 17(5) to (8) and 18(3) to (12) of the Police and Criminal Evidence (Northern Ireland) Order 1989 apply to warrants issued under this section.
This section has effect in relation to Scotland as if—

P3para.Text: for any reference to a justice of the peace there were substituted a reference to a justice of the peace or a sheriff, and
for any reference to information on oath there were substituted a reference to evidence on oath.

P2para.Text: In this section “investigator” means a person appointed under section 73.

P1group.Title: Retention of documents taken under section 78

P2para.Text: Any document of which possession is taken under section 78 (“a seized document”) may be retained so long as it is necessary to retain it (rather than copies of it) in the circumstances.

A person claiming to be the owner of a seized document may apply to a magistrates’ court or (in Scotland) the sheriff for an order for the delivery of the document to the person appearing to the court or sheriff to be the owner.

If on an application under subsection (2) the court or (in Scotland) the sheriff cannot ascertain who is the owner of the seized document the court or sheriff (as the case may be) may make such order as the court or sheriff thinks fit.
An order under subsection (2) or (3) does not affect the right of any person to take legal proceedings against any person in possession of a seized document for the recovery of the document.
Any right to bring proceedings (as described in subsection (4)) may only be exercised within 6 months of the date of the order made under subsection (2) or (3).

P1group.Title: Enforcement of information and investigation powers

P2para.Text: If a person other than an investigator (“the defaulter”) fails to comply with a requirement imposed under any of sections 71 to 78, the person imposing the requirement may certify that fact in writing to the court.

If the court is satisfied that the defaulter failed without reasonable excuse to comply with the requirement, it may deal with the defaulter (and in the case of a body corporate, any director or other officer of the body) as if that person were in contempt.
In subsection (2) “officer”, in relation to a limited liability partnership, means a member of the limited liability partnership.
A person who knows or suspects that an investigation is being or is likely to be conducted under section 73 is guilty of an offence if the person—

P3para.Text: falsifies, conceals, destroys or otherwise disposes of a document which the person knows or suspects is or would be relevant to such an investigation, or
causes or permits the falsification, concealment, destruction or disposal of such a document.

P2para.Text: It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under subsection (4) to show that the person had no intention of concealing facts disclosed by the documents from the investigator.
A person is guilty of an offence if the person, in purported compliance with a requirement imposed under any of sections 71 to 78—

P3para.Text: provides information which the person knows to be false or misleading in a material particular, or
recklessly provides information which is false or misleading in a material particular.

P2para.Text: A person guilty of an offence under subsection (4) or (6) is liable—

P3para.Text: on summary conviction—

P4para.Text: in England and Wales, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months (or 6 months, if the offence was committed before the commencement of section 154(1) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003) or a fine, or both;
in Scotland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months or a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum, or both;
in Northern Ireland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum, or both;

P3para.Text: on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 2 years or a fine, or both.

P2para.Text: Any person who intentionally obstructs the exercise of any rights conferred by a warrant under section 78 is guilty of an offence and liable on summary conviction—

P3para.Text: in England and Wales, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 51 weeks (or 3 months, if the offence was committed before the commencement of section 280(2) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003) or a fine, or both;
in Scotland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 months or a fine not exceeding level 5 on the standard scale, or both;
in Northern Ireland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 months or a fine not exceeding level 5 on the standard scale, or both.

P2para.Text: In this section—

Para.Text: “court” means the High Court or, in Scotland, the Court of Session;
“investigator” means a person appointed under section 73.

P2para.Text: The Payment Systems Regulator may give guidance consisting of such information and advice as it considers appropriate—

P3para.Text: with respect to the operation of specified provisions of this Part;
with respect to any other matter relating to its functions under this Part;
with respect to any other matters about which it appears to the Payment Systems Regulator to be desirable to give information or advice.

P2para.Text: Guidance given by the Payment Systems Regulator under this section must include guidance about how it intends to advance its payment systems objectives in discharging its functions under this Part in relation to different categories of payment system or participants in payment systems.
In this Part “general guidance” means guidance given by the Payment Systems Regulator under this section which—

P3para.Text: is given—

P4para.Text: to persons generally,
to participants in payment systems, or regulated payment systems, generally, or
to a class of participant in a payment system or regulated payment system,

P3para.Text: is intended to have continuing effect, and
is given in writing or other legible form.

P2para.Text: The Payment Systems Regulator may give financial or other assistance to persons giving information or advice of a kind which the Payment Systems Regulator could give under this section.
The Payment Systems Regulator may—

P3para.Text: publish its guidance,
offer copies of its published guidance for sale at a reasonable price, and
if it gives guidance in response to a request made by any person, make a reasonable charge for that guidance.

P2para.Text: If it considers that it is desirable to do so in order to advance any of its payment systems objectives, the Payment Systems Regulator may prepare and publish a report into any matter which it considers relevant to the exercise of its functions under this Part.

P1group.Title: Duty of regulators to ensure co-ordinated exercise of functions

P2para.Text: The following are regulators for the purposes of this section—

P3para.Text: the Payment Systems Regulator;
the Bank of England;
the FCA;
the PRA.

P2para.Text: The regulators must co-ordinate the exercise of their relevant functions (see subsection (5)) with a view to ensuring—

P3para.Text: that each regulator consults every other regulator (where not otherwise required to do so) in connection with any proposed exercise of a relevant function in a way that may have a material adverse effect on the advancement by that other regulator of any of its objectives;

that where appropriate each regulator obtains information and advice from every other regulator in connection with the exercise of its relevant functions in relation to matters of common regulatory interest in cases where the other regulator may be expected to have relevant information or relevant expertise.

P2para.Text: The duty in subsection (2) applies only to the extent that compliance with the duty—

P3para.Text: is compatible with the advancement by each regulator of any of its objectives, and
does not impose a burden on the regulators that is disproportionate to the benefits of compliance.

P2para.Text: A function conferred on a regulator relates to matters of common regulatory interest if—

P3para.Text: another regulator exercises similar or related functions in relation to the same persons,
another regulator exercises functions which relate to different persons but relate to similar subject-matter, or
its exercise could affect the advancement by another regulator of any of its objectives.

P2para.Text: “Relevant functions” means—

P3para.Text: in relation to the Payment Systems Regulator, its functions under this Part;
in relation to the Bank of England, its functions under Part 5 of the Banking Act 2009 (inter-bank payment systems);
in relation to the FCA, the functions conferred on it by or under FSMA 2000 (see section 1A(6) of that Act);
in relation to the PRA, the functions conferred on it by or under FSMA 2000 (see section 2A(6) of that Act).

P2para.Text: “Objectives” means—

P3para.Text: in relation to the Payment Systems Regulator, its payment systems objectives;
in relation to the Bank of England, its Financial Stability Objective under section 2A of the Bank of England Act 1998;
in relation to the FCA, its strategic objective and operational objectives under section 1B of FSMA 2000;
in relation to the PRA, its general objective under section 2B of that Act.

P2para.Text: The following are regulators for the purposes of this section—

P3para.Text: the Payment Systems Regulator;
the Bank of England;
the FCA;
the PRA.

P2para.Text: The regulators must prepare and maintain a memorandum which describes in general terms—

P3para.Text: the role of each regulator in relation to the exercise of relevant functions which relate to matters of common regulatory interest, and
how the regulators intend to comply with section 83 in relation to the exercise of such functions.

P2para.Text: The regulators must review the memorandum at least once in each calendar year.
The regulators must give the Treasury a copy of the memorandum and any revised memorandum.
The Treasury must lay before Parliament a copy of any document received by them under this section.
The regulators must ensure that the memorandum as currently in force is published in the way appearing to them to be best calculated to bring it to the attention of the public.
The memorandum need not relate to any aspect of compliance with section 83 if the regulators consider—

P3para.Text: that publication of information about that aspect would be against the public interest, or
that that aspect is a technical or operational matter not affecting the public.

P2para.Text: In this section—

P3para.Text: the reference in subsection (2)(a) to matters of common regulatory interest is to be read in accordance with section 83(4), and
references to relevant functions are to be read in accordance with section 83(5).

P1group.Title: Power of Bank to require Regulator to refrain from specified action

P2para.Text: Where the first, second and third conditions are met, the Bank of England may give a direction under this section to the Payment Systems Regulator.
The first condition is that the Payment Systems Regulator is proposing to exercise any of its powers under this Part in relation to a participant in a regulated payment system.
The second condition is that the Bank of England is of the opinion that the exercise of the power in the manner proposed may—

P3para.Text: threaten the stability of the UK financial system,
have serious consequences for business or other interests in the United Kingdom, or
have an adverse effect on the Bank’s ability to act in its capacity as a monetary authority.

P2para.Text: The third condition is that the Bank of England is of the opinion that the giving of the direction is necessary in order to avoid the possible consequence falling within subsection (3).
A direction under this section is a direction requiring the Payment Systems Regulator not to exercise the power or not to exercise it in a specified manner.
The direction may be expressed to have effect during a specified period or until revoked.

The Payment Systems Regulator is not required to comply with a direction under this section if or to the extent that in the opinion of the Payment Systems Regulator compliance would be incompatible with any EU obligation or any other international obligation of the United Kingdom.

P1group.Title: Power of FCA to require Regulator to refrain from specified action

P2para.Text: Where the first, second and third conditions are met, the FCA may give a direction under this section to the Payment Systems Regulator.
The first condition is that the Payment Systems Regulator is proposing to exercise any of its powers under this Part in relation to a participant in a regulated payment system.

The second condition is that the FCA is of the opinion that the exercise of the power in the manner proposed may have an adverse effect on the ability of the FCA to comply with its duty under section 1B(1) of FSMA 2000 (FCA’s general duties).
The third condition is that the FCA is of the opinion that the giving of the direction is necessary in order to avoid the possible consequence falling within subsection (3).
A direction under this section is a direction requiring the Payment Systems Regulator not to exercise the power or not to exercise it in a specified manner.
The direction may be expressed to have effect during a specified period or until revoked.
