The Payment Systems Regulator is not required to comply with a direction under this section if or to the extent that in the opinion of the Payment Systems Regulator compliance would be incompatible with any EU obligation or any other international obligation of the United Kingdom.

P1group.Title: Power of PRA to require Regulator to refrain from specified action

P2para.Text: Where the first, second and third conditions are met, the PRA may give a direction under this section to the Payment Systems Regulator.
The first condition is that the Payment Systems Regulator is proposing to exercise any of its powers under this Part in relation to—

P3para.Text: a class of PRA-authorised persons, or
a particular PRA-authorised person.

P2para.Text: The second condition is that the PRA is of the opinion that the exercise of the power in the manner proposed may—

P3para.Text: threaten the stability of the UK financial system,
result in the failure of a PRA-authorised person in a way that would have an adverse effect on the stability of the UK financial system, or
have an adverse effect on the ability of the PRA to comply with its duty under section 2B(1) of FSMA 2000 (the PRA’s general objective).

P2para.Text: The third condition is that the PRA is of the opinion that the giving of the direction is necessary in order to avoid the possible consequence falling within subsection (3).
A direction under this section is a direction requiring the Payment Systems Regulator not to exercise the power or not to exercise it in a specified manner.
The direction may be expressed to have effect during a specified period or until revoked.

The Payment Systems Regulator is not required to comply with a direction under this section if or to the extent that in the opinion of the Payment Systems Regulator compliance would be incompatible with any EU obligation or any other international obligation of the United Kingdom.
The reference in subsection (3)(b) to the “failure” of a PRA-authorised person is to be read in accordance with section 2J(3) and (4) of FSMA 2000.
In this section “PRA-authorised person” has the same meaning as in FSMA 2000 (see section 2B(5) of that Act).
The Payment Systems Regulator must make and maintain effective arrangements for consulting relevant persons on—

P3para.Text: the extent to which its general policies and practices are consistent with its general duties under section 39, and
how its payment systems objectives may best be achieved.

P2para.Text: The following are “relevant persons” for the purposes of this section—

P3para.Text: participants in regulated payment systems, and
those who use, or are likely to use, services provided by regulated payment systems.

P2para.Text: Arrangements under this section must include the establishment and maintenance of one or more panels of persons to represent the interests of relevant persons.
Where the Payment Systems Regulator establishes a panel under subsection (3), it must appoint one of the members of the panel to be its chair.
The Treasury’s approval is required for the appointment or dismissal of the chair of a panel established under subsection (3).
The Payment Systems Regulator must—

P3para.Text: consider representations that are made to it in accordance with arrangements made under this section, and
from time to time publish, in such manner as it thinks fit, responses to the representations.

P1group.Title: Consultation in relation to generally applicable requirements

P2para.Text: In this section references to imposing a generally applicable requirement are to—

P3para.Text: giving a general direction, or
imposing a requirement under section 45 that applies to all operators of regulated payment systems,

P2para.Text: and references to the requirement are to be read accordingly.
Before imposing a generally applicable requirement, the Payment Systems Regulator must—

P3para.Text: consult the Bank of England, the FCA and the PRA, and
after doing so, publish a draft of the proposed requirement in the way appearing to the Payment Systems Regulator to be best calculated to bring it to the attention of the public.

P2para.Text: The draft must be accompanied by—

P3para.Text: a cost benefit analysis,
an explanation of the purpose of the proposed requirement,
an explanation of the Payment Systems Regulator’s reasons for believing that imposing the requirement is compatible with its duties under section 39, and
notice that representations about the proposed requirement may be made to the Payment Systems Regulator within a specified time.

P2para.Text: Before imposing the proposed requirement the Payment Systems Regulator must have regard to any representations made to it in accordance with subsection (3)(d).
If the Payment Systems Regulator proposes to impose the requirement, it must publish an account, in general terms, of—

P3para.Text: the representations made to it in accordance with subsection (3)(d), and
its response to them.

P2para.Text: If the requirement differs from the draft published under subsection (2)(b) in a way which is, in the opinion of the Payment Systems Regulator, significant the Payment Systems Regulator must (in addition to complying with subsection (5)) publish details of the difference together with a cost benefit analysis.
For the purposes of this section a “cost benefit analysis” is—

P3para.Text: an analysis of the costs together with an analysis of the benefits that will arise—

P4para.Text: if the proposed requirement is imposed, or
if subsection (6) applies, from the requirement imposed, and

P3para.Text: subject to subsection (8), an estimate of those costs and of those benefits.

P2para.Text: If, in the opinion of the Payment Systems Regulator—

P3para.Text: the costs or benefits referred to in subsection (7) cannot reasonably be estimated, or
it is not reasonably practicable to produce an estimate,

P2para.Text: the cost benefit analysis need not estimate them, but must include a statement of the Payment Systems Regulator’s opinion and an explanation of it.
The Payment Systems Regulator may charge a reasonable fee for providing a person with a copy of a draft published under subsection (2)(b).

Subsections (2)(b) and (3) to (6) do not apply if the Payment Systems Regulator considers that the delay involved in complying with them would be prejudicial to the interests of those who use, or are likely to use, services provided by regulated payment systems.
Subsections (3)(a) and (6) do not apply if the Payment Systems Regulator considers that, making the appropriate comparison—

P3para.Text: there will be no increase in costs, or
there will be an increase in costs but the increase will be of minimal significance.

P2para.Text: In subsection (11) the “appropriate comparison” means—

P3para.Text: in relation to subsection (3)(a), a comparison between the overall position if the requirement is imposed and the overall position if it is not imposed;
in relation to subsection (6), a comparison between the overall position after the imposing of the requirement and the overall position before it was imposed.

P2para.Text: Section 68 of the Financial Services Act 2012 (cases in which Treasury may arrange independent inquiries) is amended as follows.
In subsection (1), for “two” substitute “three”.
After subsection (3) insert—
The third case is where it appears to the Treasury that—

P3para.Text: events have occurred in relation to a regulated payment system which caused or risked causing significant damage to business or other interests throughout the United Kingdom, and
those events might not have occurred, or the threat or damage might have been reduced, but for a serious failure in—

P4para.Text: the system established by Part 5 of the Financial Services (Banking Reform) Act 2013 for the regulation of payment systems, or
the operation of that system.

P2para.Text: In section 83(1) (interpretation), after the definition of “regulated activity” insert—

Para.Text: “regulated payment system” has the same meaning as in Part 5 of the Financial Services (Banking Reform) Act 2013 (see section 95 of that Act);

P2para.Text: Part 5 of the Financial Services Act 2012 (inquiries and investigations) is amended as follows.
After section 76 insert—

P1group.Title: Duty of Payment Systems Regulator to investigate and report on possible regulatory failure

P2para.Text: Subsection (3) applies where it appears to the Payment Systems Regulator that—

P3para.Text: events have occurred in relation to a regulated payment system which had or could have had a significant adverse effect on effective competition in the interests of—

P4para.Text: participants in the payment system, or
those who use, or are likely to use, the services provided by the payment system, and

P3para.Text: those events might not have occurred, or the adverse effect might have been reduced, but for a serious failure in—

P4para.Text: the system established by Part 5 of the Financial Services (Banking Reform) Act 2013 for the regulation of payment systems, or
the operation of that system.

P2para.Text: Subsection (3) also applies where the Treasury direct the Payment Systems Regulator that it appears to the Treasury that the conditions in subsection (1) are met in relation to specified events.
The Payment Systems Regulator must carry out an investigation into the events and the circumstances surrounding them and report to the Treasury on the result of the investigation.
Subsection (3) does not apply by virtue of subsection (1) if the Treasury direct the Payment Systems Regulator that it is not required to carry out an investigation into the events concerned.
In this section “participant”, in relation to a regulated payment system, has the same meaning as in Part 5 of the Financial Services (Banking Reform) Act 2013 (see section 33 of that Act).
In section 77 (power of Treasury to require FCA or PRA to undertake investigation)—

P3para.Text: in subsection (1)(a), for “either regulator” substitute “a regulator”;
in subsection (3), omit the “or” at the end of paragraph (b) and after paragraph (c) insert
a regulated payment system.
the heading of that section becomes “Power of Treasury to require regulator to undertake investigation”.

P2para.Text: In section 78 (conduct of investigation), in subsection (1), for “or 74” substitute “, 74 or 76A”.
In section 79 (conclusion of investigation), for “or 74” substitute “, 74 or 76A”.
In section 80 (statements of policy), in subsection (1)(a), for “or 74” substitute “, 74 or 76A”.
In section 81 (publication of directions), in subsection (1), after paragraph (b) insert—

P3para.Text: section 76A(4);

P2para.Text: In section 83(1) (interpretation)—

P3para.Text: after the definition of “listed securities” insert—

Para.Text: “the Payment Systems Regulator” means the body established under section 31 of the Financial Services (Banking Reform) Act 2013;

P3para.Text: in the definition of “regulator”, for “or the PRA” substitute “, the PRA or the Payment Systems Regulator”.

P2para.Text: Chapter 4 of Part 9A of FSMA 2000 (competition scrutiny) applies to the Payment Systems Regulator’s practices and regulating provisions in relation to payment systems as it applies to the FCA’s practices and regulating provisions within the meaning of that Chapter.
In subsection (1)—

P3para.Text: the reference to the Payment Systems Regulator’s practices in relation to payment systems is a reference to practices adopted by it in the exercise of functions under this Part, and
the reference to the Payment Systems Regulator’s regulating provisions in relation to payment systems is a reference to the following—

P4para.Text: any general directions given under section 44;
any requirements imposed under section 45 on all operators of regulated payment systems;
any guidance given under section 81.

P1group.Title: Relationship with Part 8 of the Payment Services Regulations 2009

P2para.Text: The Payment Systems Regulator may not exercise any power under this Part for the purposes of enabling a relevant person to obtain access to, or otherwise participate in, a payment system if the payment system is one to which Part 8 of the Payment Services Regulations 2009 (S.I. 2009/209) does not apply.

A person is a “relevant person” for the purposes of subsection (1) if regulation 97 of the Payment Services Regulations 2009 (prohibition on restrictive rules on access to payment systems) applies in relation to access to, or participation in, a payment system by the person.

P1group.Title: Exemption from liability in damages for FCA and PRA

P2para.Text: In paragraph 25 of Schedule 1ZA to FSMA 2000 (FCA’s exemption from liability in damages), after sub-paragraph (1) insert—
In sub-paragraph (1) the reference to the FCA’s functions includes its functions under Part 5 of the Financial Services (Banking Reform) Act 2013 (regulation of payment systems).
In paragraph 33 of Schedule 1ZB to FSMA 2000 (PRA’s exemption from liability in damages), after sub-paragraph (1) insert—
In sub-paragraph (1) the reference to the PRA’s functions includes its functions under Part 5 of the Financial Services (Banking Reform) Act 2013 (regulation of payment systems).
For provision conferring immunity from liability in damages on the Bank of England in respect of its functions, see section 244 of the Banking Act 2009.
In this Part—

Para.Text: “compliance failure” has the meaning given by section 61;
“designation order” has the meaning given by section 34;
“direct access”, in relation to a payment system, is to be read in accordance with section 33(6);

“document” includes information recorded in any form and, in relation to information recorded otherwise than in legible form, references to its production include references to producing a copy of the information
in legible form or in a form from which it can readily be produced in visible and legible form;
“general direction” has the meaning given by section 44(5);
“general guidance” has the meaning given by section 81(3);
“infrastructure provider”, in relation to a payment system, has the meaning given by section 33(4);
“operator”, in relation to a payment system, has the meaning given by section 33(3);
“participant”, in relation to a payment system, has the meaning given by section 33 (and references to participation in a payment system are to be read in accordance with that section);
“payment service provider”, in relation to a payment system, has the meaning given by section 33(5);
“payment system” has the meaning given by section 32;
“recognised inter-bank payment system” means an inter-bank payment system (within the meaning of Part 5 of the Banking Act 2009) specified as a recognised system for the purposes of that Part;
“regulated payment system” means a payment system designated as a regulated payment system by a designation order;
“the UK financial system” has the meaning given by section 1I of FSMA 2000.

P2para.Text: References in this Part to the Payment Systems Regulator’s payment systems objectives are to be read in accordance with section 39(2).
References in this Part to the Bank of England’s capacity as a monetary authority are to be read in accordance with section 244 of the Banking Act 2009.

Part.Title: Special administration for operators of certain infrastructure systems

P1para.Text: This Part—

P3para.Text: provides for a procedure to be known as FMI administration, and
restricts the powers of persons other than the Bank of England in relation to the insolvency of infrastructure companies.

P2para.Text: In this Part “infrastructure company” has the meaning given by this section.
“Infrastructure company” means a company which is—

P3para.Text: the operator of a recognised inter-bank payment system, other than an operator excluded by subsection (3),
approved under regulations under section 785 of the Companies Act 2006 (provision enabling procedures for evidencing and transferring title) as the operator of a securities settlement system, or
a company designated by the Treasury under subsection (4).

P2para.Text: But a company is not an infrastructure company if it is a recognised central counterparty, as defined by section 285 of FSMA 2000.
The Treasury may by order designate a company for the purposes of subsection (2)(c) if—

P3para.Text: the company provides services to a person falling within subsection (2)(a) or (b), and

the Treasury are satisfied that an interruption in the provision of those services would have a serious adverse effect on the effective operation of the recognised inter-bank payment system or securities settlement system in question.

P2para.Text: An order under subsection (4) must specify the recognised inter-bank payment system or securities settlement system in connection with which the company is designated.
Before designating a company under subsection (4), the Treasury must consult—

P3para.Text: the company to be designated,
the person within subsection (2)(a) or (b) to whom the company provides services,
the Bank of England,
if the company is a PRA-authorised person, the PRA and the FCA, and
if the company is an authorised person other than a PRA-authorised person, the FCA.

P2para.Text: In this Part—

Para.Text: “company” means a company registered under the Companies Act 2006;
“operator”, in relation to a recognised inter-bank payment system, is to be read in accordance with section 183 of the Banking Act 2009;

“recognised inter-bank payment system” means an inter-bank payment system, as defined by section 182 of the Banking Act 2009, in respect of which a recognition order under section 184 of that Act is in force;
“the relevant system” means—
in relation to an infrastructure company falling within subsection (2)(a) of section 97, the recognised inter-bank payment system,
in relation to an infrastructure company falling within subsection (2)(b) of that section, the securities settlement system,
in relation to a company designated under subsection (4) of that section, the recognised inter-bank payment system or securities settlement system falling within paragraph (b) of that subsection;

“securities settlement system” means a computer-based system, and procedures, which enable title to units of a security to be evidenced and transferred without a written instrument, and which facilitate supplementary and incidental matters.

P2para.Text: Expressions used in the definition of “securities settlement system” in subsection (1) are to be read in accordance with section 783 of the Companies Act 2006.
In this Part “FMI administration order” means an order which—

P3para.Text: is made by the court in relation to an infrastructure company, and
directs that, while the order is in force, the affairs, business and property of the company are to be managed by a person appointed by the court.

P2para.Text: A person appointed as mentioned in subsection (1)(b) is referred to in this Part as an FMI administrator.
The FMI administrator of a company must manage its affairs, business and property, and exercise and perform the FMI administrator’s functions, so as to achieve the objective in section 100.
Where an FMI administrator is appointed in relation to the operator of a recognised inter-bank payment system or a securities settlement system, the objective of the FMI administration is—

P3para.Text: to ensure that the system is and continues to be maintained and operated as an efficient and effective system,

where the operator of the system is also a clearing house falling within section 285(1)(b)(ii) of FSMA 2000 (recognised clearing house that is not a recognised central counterparty), to ensure that the protected activities continue to be carried on, and
to ensure by one or both of the specified means that it becomes unnecessary for the FMI administration order to remain in force for that purpose or those purposes.

P2para.Text: Where an FMI administrator is appointed in relation to a company designated under subsection (4) of section 97, the objective of the FMI administration is—

P3para.Text: to ensure that services falling within that subsection continue to be provided, and
to ensure by one or both of the specified means that it becomes unnecessary for the FMI administration order to remain in force for that purpose.

P2para.Text: The protected activities referred to in subsection (1)(b) are such activities as the Bank of England may from time to time direct, which must be—

P3para.Text: regulated activities falling within section 285(3)(a) or (b) of FSMA 2000, or
related activities which are necessary for the efficient carrying on of any of those regulated activities.

P2para.Text: The specified means are—

P3para.Text: the rescue as a going concern of the company subject to the FMI administration order, and
transfers falling within subsection (5).

P2para.Text: A transfer falls within this subsection if it is a transfer as a going concern—

P3para.Text: to another company, or
as respects different parts of the undertaking of the company subject to the FMI administration order, to two or more different companies,

P2para.Text: of so much of that undertaking as it is appropriate to transfer for the purpose of achieving the objective of the FMI administration.
The means by which transfers falling within subsection (5) may be effected include, in particular—

P3para.Text: a transfer of the undertaking of the company subject to the FMI administration order, or of part of its undertaking, to a wholly-owned subsidiary of that company, and
the transfer to a company of securities of a wholly-owned subsidiary to which there has been a transfer falling within paragraph (a).

P2para.Text: The objective of the FMI administration may be achieved by transfers falling within subsection (5) only to the extent that—

P3para.Text: the rescue as a going concern of the company subject to the FMI administration order is not reasonably practicable or is not reasonably practicable without such transfers,
the rescue of that company as a going concern will not achieve that objective or will not do so without such transfers, or
such transfers would produce a result for the company’s creditors as a whole that is better than the result that would be produced without them.

P2para.Text: An application for an FMI administration order may be made to the court by the Bank of England.
An application must nominate a person to be appointed as the FMI administrator.
The infrastructure company must be given notice of an application, in accordance with rules under section 411 of the 1986 Act (as applied in relation to FMI administration).
The court may make an FMI administration order in relation to an infrastructure company if satisfied—

P3para.Text: that the company is unable to pay its debts,
that the company is likely to be unable to pay its debts, or

that, on a petition presented by the Secretary of State under section 124A of the 1986 Act (petition for winding up on grounds of public interest), it would be just and equitable (disregarding the objective of the FMI administration) to wind up the company.

P2para.Text: The court may not make an FMI administration order on the ground set out in subsection (1)(c) unless the Secretary of State has certified to the court that the case is one in which the Secretary of State considers (disregarding the objective of the FMI administration) that it would be appropriate to petition under section 124A of the 1986 Act.
On an application for an FMI administration order, the court may—

P3para.Text: grant the application;
dismiss the application;
adjourn the application (generally or to a specified date);
make an interim order;
treat the application as a winding-up petition and make any order which the court could make under section 125 of the 1986 Act;
make any other order which the court thinks appropriate.

P2para.Text: An interim order under subsection (3)(d) may, in particular—

P3para.Text: restrict the exercise of a power of the company or of its directors;
make provision conferring a discretion on the court or on a person qualified to act as an insolvency practitioner in relation to the company.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of this section a company is unable to pay its debts if it is treated as being so unable under section 123 of the 1986 Act (definition of inability to pay debts).
The FMI administrator of a company—

P3para.Text: is an officer of the court, and
in exercising and performing powers and duties in relation to the company, is the company’s agent.

P2para.Text: The management by the FMI administrator of a company of any of its affairs, business or property must be carried out for the purpose of achieving the objective of the FMI administration as quickly and efficiently as is reasonably practicable.
The FMI administrator of a company must exercise and perform powers and duties in the way which, so far as it is consistent with the objective of the FMI administration to do so, best protects—

P3para.Text: the interests of the company’s creditors as a whole, and
subject to those interests, the interests of the company’s members as a whole.

P2para.Text: This section applies where, before the commencement of FMI administration, the infrastructure company had entered into arrangements with a supplier for the provision of a supply to the infrastructure company.
After the commencement of FMI administration, the supplier—

P3para.Text: must not terminate a supply unless—

P4para.Text: any charges in respect of the supply which relate to a supply given after the commencement of FMI administration remain unpaid for more than 28 days,
the FMI administrator consents to the termination, or
the supplier has the permission of the court, which may be given if the supplier can show that the continued provision of the supply would cause the supplier to suffer hardship,

P3para.Text: must not make it a condition of a supply that any charges in respect of the supply which relate to a supply given before the commencement of FMI administration are paid, and
must not do anything which has the effect of making it a condition of the giving of a supply that any charges within paragraph (b) are paid.

P2para.Text: Where, before the commencement of FMI administration, a contractual right to terminate a supply has arisen but has not been exercised, then, for the purposes of this section, the commencement of FMI administration causes that right to lapse and the supply is only to be terminated if a ground in subsection (2)(a) applies.

Any provision in a contract between the infrastructure company and the supplier that purports to terminate the agreement if any action is taken to put the infrastructure company in FMI administration is void.

Any expenses incurred by the infrastructure company on the provision of a supply after the commencement of FMI administration are to be treated as necessary disbursements in the course of the FMI administration.
In this section—

Para.Text: “commencement of FMI administration” means the making of the FMI administration order;

“supplier” means the person controlling the provision of a supply to the infrastructure company, and includes a company that is a group undertaking (as defined by section 1161(5) of the Companies Act 2006) in respect of the infrastructure company;
“supply” means a supply of any of the following—
computer hardware or software used by the infrastructure company in connection with the operation of the relevant system;
financial data;
infrastructure permitting electronic communication services;
data processing;
access to secure data networks used by the infrastructure company in connection with the operation of the relevant system.

P2para.Text: If the Bank of England considers it necessary to do so for the purpose of achieving the objective of an FMI administration, the Bank may direct the FMI administrator to take, or refrain from taking, specified action.
In deciding whether to give a direction under this section, the Bank of England must have regard to the public interest in—

P3para.Text: the protection and enhancement of the stability of the financial system of the United Kingdom, and
the maintenance of public confidence in that system.

P2para.Text: A direction under this section must not be incompatible with a direction of the court that is in force under Schedule B1 to the 1986 Act.
The Bank of England must, within a reasonable time of giving the direction, give the FMI administrator a statement of its reasons for giving the direction.
A person listed in subsection (6) has immunity from liability in damages in respect of action or inaction in accordance with a direction under this section.
Those persons are—

P3para.Text: the FMI administrator;
the company in FMI administration;
the officers or staff of the company.

P2para.Text: Immunity conferred by this section does not extend to action or inaction—

P3para.Text: in bad faith, or
in contravention of section 6(1) of the Human Rights Act 1998.

P2para.Text: This section does not limit the powers conferred on the Bank of England by section 191 of the Banking Act 2009 (directions) in relation to a recognised inter-bank payment system.

P1group.Title: Conduct of administration, transfer schemes etc.

P2para.Text: Schedule 6 (which applies the provisions of Schedule B1 to the 1986 Act about ordinary administration orders and certain other enactments to FMI administration orders) has effect.
Schedule 7 (which makes provision for transfer schemes to achieve the objective of an FMI administration) has effect.

The power to make rules conferred by section 411(1B) of the 1986 Act (rules relating to bank administration) is to apply for the purpose of giving effect to this Part as it applies for the purposes of giving effect to Part 3 of the Banking Act 2009 (and, accordingly, as if the reference in section 411(1B) to that Part included a reference to this Part).

P1group.Title: Restriction on winding-up orders and voluntary winding up

P2para.Text: A petition by a person other than the Bank of England for a winding up order in respect of an infrastructure company may not be determined unless—

P3para.Text: the petitioner has notified the Bank of England that the petition has been presented, and
the period of 14 days beginning with the day on which the notice is received by the Bank has ended.

P2para.Text: A resolution for the voluntary winding up of an infrastructure company may not be made unless—

P3para.Text: the infrastructure company has applied to the court under this section,
the company has notified the Bank of England that the application has been made, and
after the end of the period of 14 days beginning with the day on which the notice is received by the Bank, the court gives permission for the resolution to be made.

P1group.Title: Restriction on making of ordinary administration orders

P2para.Text: This section applies where an ordinary administration application is made in relation to an infrastructure company by a person other than the Bank of England.
The court must dismiss the application if—

P3para.Text: an FMI administration order is in force in relation to the company, or
an FMI administration order has been made in relation to the company but is not yet in force.

P2para.Text: Where subsection (2) does not apply, the court, on hearing the application, must not exercise its powers under paragraph 13 of Schedule B1 to the 1986 Act (other than its power of adjournment) unless—

P3para.Text: the applicant has notified the Bank of England that the application has been made, and
the period of 14 days beginning with the day on which the notice is received by the Bank has ended.

P2para.Text: On the making of an FMI administration order in relation to an infrastructure company, the court must dismiss any ordinary administration application made in relation to the company which is outstanding.
“Ordinary administration application” means an application under paragraph 12 of Schedule B1 to the 1986 Act.

P1para.Text: A person may not take any step to enforce a security over property of an infrastructure company unless—

P3para.Text: notice of the intention to do so has been given to the Bank of England, and
the period of 14 days beginning with the day on which the notice was received by the Bank has ended.

Pblock.Title: Financial support for companies in FMI administration

P2para.Text: This section applies where an FMI administration order has been made in relation to an infrastructure company.
The Treasury may, out of money provided by Parliament, make loans to the company for achieving the objective in section 100.
A loan under this section may be made on such terms as the Treasury think fit.
The Treasury must pay into the Consolidated Fund sums received by them as a result of this section.
This section applies where an FMI administration order has been made in relation to an infrastructure company.
The Treasury may agree to indemnify persons in respect of one or both of the following—

P3para.Text: liabilities incurred in connection with the exercise of powers and duties by the FMI administrator;
loss or damage sustained in that connection.

P2para.Text: The agreement may be made in whatever manner, and on whatever terms, the Treasury think fit.
As soon as practicable after agreeing to indemnify persons under this section, the Treasury must lay before Parliament a statement of the agreement.
If sums are paid by the Treasury in consequence of an indemnity agreed to under this section, the infrastructure company must pay the Treasury—

P3para.Text: such amounts in or towards the repayment to them of those sums as the Treasury may direct, and
interest, at such rates as they may direct, on amounts outstanding under this subsection.

P2para.Text: Subsection (5) does not apply in the case of a sum paid by the Treasury for indemnifying a person in respect of a liability to the infrastructure company.
Where a sum has been paid out by the Treasury in consequence of an indemnity agreed to under this section, the Treasury must lay a statement relating to that sum before Parliament—

P3para.Text: as soon as practicable after the end of the financial year in which that sum is paid out, and
(except where subsection (5) does not apply in the case of the sum) as soon as practicable after the end of each subsequent relevant financial year.

P2para.Text: In relation to a sum paid out in consequence of an indemnity, a financial year is a relevant financial year for the purposes of subsection (7) unless—

P3para.Text: before the beginning of that year, the whole of that sum has been repaid to the Treasury under subsection (5), and
the infrastructure company is not at any time during that year subject to liability to pay interest on amounts that became due under that subsection in respect of that sum.

P2para.Text: The power of the Treasury to agree to indemnify persons—

P3para.Text: is confined to a power to agree to indemnify persons in respect of liabilities, loss and damage incurred or sustained by them as relevant persons, but
includes power to agree to indemnify persons (whether or not they are identified or identifiable at the time of the agreement) who subsequently become relevant persons.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of this section each of the following is a relevant person—

P3para.Text: the FMI administrator;
an employee of the FMI administrator;
a member or employee of a firm of which the FMI administrator is a member;
a member or employee of a firm of which the FMI administrator is an employee;
a member or employee of a firm of which the FMI administrator was an employee or member at a time when the order was in force;
a body corporate which is the employer of the FMI administrator;
an officer, employee or member of such a body corporate.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of subsection (10)—

P3para.Text: the references to the FMI administrator are to be read, where two or more persons are appointed to act as the FMI administrator, as references to any one or more of them, and

the references to a firm of which a person was a member or employee at a particular time include references to a firm which holds itself out to be the successor of a firm of which the person was a member or employee at that time.

P2para.Text: The Treasury must pay into the Consolidated Fund sums received by them as a result of subsection (5).
In this Part—

Para.Text: “the 1986 Act” means the Insolvency Act 1986;
“business”, “member”, “property” and “security” have the same meaning as in the 1986 Act;
“company” has the meaning given by section 98;
“the court” means—
in England and Wales and Northern Ireland, the High Court;
in Scotland, the Court of Session;
“FMI administration order” and “FMI administrator” are to be read in accordance with section 99;
“infrastructure company” has the meaning given by section 97;
“operator”, in relation to a recognised inter-bank payment system, has the meaning given by section 98;
“recognised inter-bank payment system” has the meaning given by section 98;
“regulated activity” has the same meaning as in FSMA 2000;
“the relevant system” has the meaning given by section 98;
“securities settlement system” has the meaning given by section 98.

P2para.Text: In this Part references to the FMI administrator of a company include a person appointed under paragraph 91 or 103 of Schedule B1 to the 1986 Act, as applied by Schedule 6 to this Act, to be the FMI administrator of a company.

In this Part references to a person qualified to act as an insolvency practitioner in relation to a company are to be read in accordance with Part 13 of the 1986 Act, but as if references in that Part to a company included a company registered under the Companies Act 2006 in Northern Ireland.

Pblock.Title: Application of Part to Northern Ireland

P2para.Text: This section makes provision about this Part in its application to Northern Ireland.
Any reference to any provision of the 1986 Act is to have effect as a reference to the corresponding provision of the Insolvency (Northern Ireland) Order 1989.
Section 112(3) is to have effect as if the reference to Northern Ireland were a reference to England and Wales or Scotland.

P1group.Title: Functions of FCA under competition legislation

P1para.Text: Schedule 8 (which contains provision conferring on the FCA functions under competition legislation) has effect.

P1group.Title: Competition as a secondary objective of the PRA

P2para.Text: For section 2H of FSMA 2000 substitute—

P1group.Title: Secondary competition objective and duty to have regard to regulatory principles

P2para.Text: When discharging its general functions in a way that advances its objectives (see section 2F), the PRA must so far as is reasonably possible act in a way which, as a secondary objective, facilitates effective competition in the markets for services provided by PRA-authorised persons in carrying on regulated activities.
In discharging its general functions, the PRA must also have regard to the regulatory principles in section 3B.
In section 3B (regulatory principles to be applied by both regulators), in subsection (1), for “2H(1)(a)” substitute “2H(2)”.
In Schedule 1ZB to FSMA 2000 (the Prudential Regulation Authority)—

P3para.Text: in paragraph 19 (annual report), in sub-paragraph (1)—

P4para.Text: after paragraph (b) insert—

P3para.Text: how it has complied with section 2H(1),

P4para.Text: in paragraph (c), omit the words from “and of” onwards, and

P3para.Text: in paragraph 20 (consultation about annual report), in sub-paragraph (1)(c), for the words from “and the PRA” onwards substitute “and the PRA has facilitated effective competition in accordance with section 2H and has considered the regulatory principles in section 3B”.

P1group.Title: Power of FCA and PRA to make rules applying to parent undertakings

P2para.Text: After section 192J of FSMA 2000 insert—

Pblock.Title: Rules applying to parent undertakings of ring-fenced bodies

P1group.Title: Rules applying to parent undertakings of ring-fenced bodies

P2para.Text: The appropriate regulator may make such rules applying to bodies corporate falling within subsection (2) as appear to the regulator to be necessary or expedient for the group ring-fencing purposes.
A body corporate falls within this subsection if—

P3para.Text: it is incorporated in the United Kingdom or has a place of business in the United Kingdom,
it is a parent undertaking of a ring-fenced body, and
it is not itself an authorised person.

P2para.Text: The “group ring-fencing purposes” are the purposes set out in section 142H(4).
“The appropriate regulator” means—

P3para.Text: in relation to the parent undertaking of a ring-fenced body that is a PRA-authorised person, the PRA;
in any other case, the FCA.

Pblock.Title: Rules requiring parent undertakings to facilitate resolution

P1group.Title: Rules requiring parent undertakings to facilitate resolution

P2para.Text: The appropriate regulator may make rules requiring a qualifying parent undertaking to make arrangements that would in the opinion of the regulator allow or facilitate the exercise of the resolution powers in relation to the qualifying parent undertaking or any of its subsidiary undertakings in the event of a situation arising where all or part of the business of the parent undertaking or the subsidiary undertaking encounters or is likely to encounter financial difficulties.
The “resolution powers” are—

P3para.Text: the powers conferred on the Treasury and the Bank of England by or under Parts 1 to 3 of the Banking Act 2009, and
any similar powers exercisable by an authority outside the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: The arrangements that may be required include arrangements relating to—

P3para.Text: the issue of debt instruments by the parent undertaking;

the provision to a subsidiary undertaking (“S”) or a transferee by the parent undertaking, or by any other subsidiary undertaking of the parent undertaking, of such services and facilities as would be required to enable S or the transferee to operate the business, or part of the business, effectively.

P2para.Text: In subsection (3)(b) “transferee” means a person to whom all or part of the business of the parent undertaking or the subsidiary undertaking could be transferred as a result of the exercise of the resolution powers.
“Debt instrument” has the same meaning as in section 142Y.
“The appropriate regulator” means—

P3para.Text: where the subsidiary undertakings of the qualifying parent undertaking include a ring-fenced body that is a PRA-authorised person, the PRA;

where the subsidiary undertakings of the qualifying parent undertaking include one or more PRA-authorised persons but do not include any authorised person that is not a PRA-authorised person, the PRA;
where the subsidiary undertakings of the qualifying parent undertaking do not include any PRA-authorised person, the FCA;
in any other case, the PRA or the FCA.

P2para.Text: In section 192K of FSMA 2000 (power to impose penalty or issue censure)—

P3para.Text: in subsection (1), after “section 192J” insert “or 192JB”, and
after that subsection insert—

P2para.Text: This section also applies if a regulator is satisfied that a person (“P”) who is or has been a parent undertaking of a ring-fenced body has contravened a provision of rules made by that regulator under section 192JA.

P1group.Title: Fees to meet Treasury expenditure relating to international organisations

P1para.Text: After section 410 of FSMA 2000 insert—

P1group.Title: Fees to meet certain expenses of the Treasury

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by regulations—

P3para.Text: enable the Treasury from time to time by direction to require the FCA, the PRA or the Bank of England (each a “regulator”) to require the payment of fees by relevant persons, or such class of relevant person as may be specified in, or determined by the regulator in accordance with, the direction, for the purpose of meeting relevant expenses incurred by the Treasury;
make provision about how the regulator to which a direction is given is to comply with the direction;
require the regulator to pay to the Treasury, by such time or times as may be specified in the direction, the amount of any fees received by the regulator.

P2para.Text: “Relevant expenses” are expenses (including any expenses of a capital nature) which are attributable to United Kingdom membership of, or Treasury participation in, a prescribed international organisation so far as those expenses—

P3para.Text: represent a contribution (by way of subscription or otherwise) to the resources of the international organisation, and
are in the opinion of the Treasury attributable to functions of the organisation which relate to financial stability or financial services.

P2para.Text: The regulations must provide for the charging of fees in pursuance of a direction given under the regulations to the FCA or the PRA to be by rules made by that regulator.
The provisions of Chapter 2 of Part 9A apply to rules of the FCA or the PRA providing for the charging of fees in pursuance of a direction given under the regulations—

P3para.Text: in the case of the FCA, as they apply to rules relating to the payment of fees under paragraph 23 of Schedule 1ZA;
in the case of the PRA, as they apply to rules relating to the payment of fees under paragraph 31 of Schedule 1ZB.

P2para.Text: Paragraph 36(1) of Schedule 17A applies to the charging of fees by the Bank of England in pursuance of a direction given to the Bank under the regulations.
The regulations may in particular—

P3para.Text: make provision about what is, or is not, to be regarded as an expense;
specify requirements that the Treasury must comply with before giving a direction;
enable a direction to be varied or revoked by a subsequent direction;
confer functions on a regulator.

P2para.Text: An amount payable to a regulator as a result of—

P3para.Text: any provision of rules made by the FCA or the PRA as a result of the regulations, or
the imposition of fees by the Bank of England as a result of a direction given under the regulations to the Bank,

P2para.Text: may be recovered as a debt due to the regulator.
“Relevant persons” means—

P3para.Text: in the case of a direction given to the PRA, PRA-authorised persons;
in the case of a direction given to the FCA, authorised persons and recognised investment exchanges who (in either case) are not PRA-authorised persons;
in the case of a direction given to the Bank of England, recognised clearing houses, other than those falling within paragraph (a) or (b).

P2para.Text: This section is subject to section 410B.
In this section “a fees direction” means a direction given by the Treasury as a result of regulations under section 410A.
Before giving a fees direction to the FCA, the PRA or the Bank of England (each a “regulator”), the Treasury must consult the regulator concerned.
A fees direction must—

P3para.Text: be in writing;

except in the case of a direction that revokes a previous direction or a direction that varies a previous direction without affecting the total amount intended to be raised by the fees, specify the total amount intended to be raised by the fees to be charged by the regulator and explain how that amount is calculated;
contain such other information as may be prescribed.

P2para.Text: As soon as practicable after giving a fees direction, the Treasury must lay before Parliament a copy of the direction.

Pblock.Title: Parliamentary control of statutory instruments under FSMA 2000

P2para.Text: Section 429 of FSMA 2000 (Parliamentary control of statutory instruments) is amended as follows.
In subsection (1)(a) (orders subject to affirmative procedure)—

P3para.Text: after “213(1A),” insert “234I(2),”.

P2para.Text: In subsection (2) (regulations subject to affirmative procedure), after “90B,” insert “142W,”.
After subsection (2) insert—
Regulations to which subsection (2B) applies are not to be made unless a draft of the regulations has been laid before Parliament and approved by a resolution of each House.
This subsection applies to regulations which contain provision made under section 410A, other than provision made only by virtue of subsection (2) of that section.
In subsection (8), for “or 23A” substitute “, 23A or 142Z”.

P1group.Title: Accounts of Bank of England and its wholly-owned subsidiaries

P2para.Text: The Bank of England Act 1998 is amended as follows.
In section 7 (accounts), in subsection (4), for the words from “appropriate” to the end substitute “necessary to do so having regard to the Financial Stability Objective”.
After section 7 insert—

P1group.Title: Accounts of companies wholly owned by the Bank

P2para.Text: If the Bank considers it necessary to do so having regard to the Financial Stability Objective, the Bank may by direction to a qualifying company exclude the application to the qualifying company of any of the relevant Companies Act requirements.

The relevant Companies Act requirements are the requirements to which the directors of the qualifying company would otherwise be subject under the Companies Act 2006 (except sections 412 and 413 (directors’ benefits)) in relation to the preparation of accounts under section 394 of that Act.

A direction under subsection (1) may relate to one or more specified accounting periods of the qualifying company, or to a specified accounting period and all subsequent accounting periods of the qualifying company.
The Bank must consult the Treasury before giving a direction under subsection (1).

The Treasury may by notice in writing to the Bank require it to publish in such manner as it thinks fit such information relating to the accounts of a qualifying company as the Treasury may specify in the notice.

The information specified in a notice under subsection (5) may include information which as a result of a direction under subsection (1) was excluded from accounts prepared in accordance with the Companies Act 2006.
The Treasury must consult the Bank before giving a notice under subsection (5).
A direction under subsection (1) or a notice under subsection (5) may be revoked by a subsequent direction or notice (as the case may be).
“Qualifying company” means any company which is wholly owned by the Bank other than—

P3para.Text: the Prudential Regulation Authority, or
a company which is a bridge bank for the purposes of section 12(3) of the Banking Act 2009.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of subsection (9), a company is wholly owned by the Bank if—

P3para.Text: it is a company of which no person other than the Bank or a nominee of the Bank is a member, or
it is a wholly-owned subsidiary of a company within paragraph (a).

P1para.Text: Schedule 9 (which contains provision about building societies) has effect.
Schedule 10 (which contains amendments of, or connected with, the Financial Services Act 2012 and amendments of provisions amended by that Act) has effect.

P2para.Text: Any power of the Treasury to make an order or regulations under this Act is exercisable by statutory instrument.
A statutory instrument containing an order or regulations under this Act is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament, unless—

P3para.Text: the instrument contains only provision made under section 127 (commencement), or
the instrument is required by subsection (4) or any other enactment to be laid in draft before, and approved by a resolution of, each House.

P2para.Text: Subsection (4) applies to a statutory instrument that contains (with or without other provisions)—

P3para.Text: regulations under section 8 (building societies: power to make provision about ring-fencing);
an order under section 32(4) (meaning of “payment system”);
an order under section 124 (power to make further consequential amendments) that amends or repeals primary legislation;
an order under paragraph 6 of Schedule 6 (conduct of FMI administration).

P2para.Text: A statutory instrument to which this subsection applies may not be made unless a draft of the instrument has been laid before, and approved by a resolution of, each House of Parliament.
In subsection (3)(c) “primary legislation” means—

P3para.Text: an Act of Parliament,
an Act of the Scottish Parliament,
a Measure or Act of the National Assembly for Wales, or
Northern Ireland legislation.

P1para.Text: In this Act—

Para.Text: “enactment” includes—
an enactment contained in subordinate legislation,
an enactment contained in, or in an instrument made under, an Act of the Scottish Parliament,
an enactment contained in, or in an instrument made under, a Measure or Act of the National Assembly for Wales, and
an enactment contained in, or in an instrument made under, Northern Ireland legislation;
“the FCA” means the Financial Conduct Authority;
“FSMA 2000” means the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000;
“the PRA” means the Prudential Regulation Authority.

P1group.Title: Power to make further consequential amendments

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by order make such provision amending, repealing, revoking or applying with modifications any enactment to which this section applies as they consider necessary or expedient in consequence of any provision made by or under this Act.
This section applies to—

P3para.Text: any enactment passed or made before the passing of this Act, and
any enactment passed or made on or before the last day of the Session in which this Act is passed.

P2para.Text: Amendments and repeals made under this section are additional to those made by or under any other provision of this Act.

The Treasury may by order make such provision as they consider necessary or expedient for transitory, transitional or saving purposes in connection with the commencement of any provision made by or under this Act.
An order under this section may—

P3para.Text: confer functions on the FCA or the PRA;
modify, exclude or apply (with or without modifications) any enactment (including any provision of, or made under, this Act).

P1para.Text: The provisions of this Act extend to England and Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland, except that the amendments made by section 9 (preferential debts: Great Britain) have the same extent as the enactments amended.

P2para.Text: This Part comes into force on the day on which this Act is passed.
Section 120 and Schedule 9, apart from paragraph 4 of that Schedule, come into force at the end of the period of 2 months beginning with the day on which this Act is passed.
The remaining provisions of this Act come into force on such day as the Treasury may by order appoint.
Different days may be appointed for different purposes.
This Act may be cited as the Financial Services (Banking Reform) Act 2013.

P1para.Text: Part 7 of FSMA 2000 (control of business transfer schemes) is amended as follows.
For “the authorised person concerned”, wherever occurring in Part 7 (including Schedule 12), substitute “the transferor concerned”.

P2para.Text: Section 103A (meaning of “the appropriate regulator”) is amended as follows.
In subsection (1), in paragraph (a), for “a scheme” substitute “a ring-fencing transfer scheme or a scheme (other than a ring-fencing transfer scheme)”.
At the end of subsection (2) insert—

P3para.Text: in the case of a ring-fencing transfer scheme, means the body to whose business the scheme relates.

P1para.Text: In section 106 (banking business transfer schemes), at the end of subsection (1)(c) insert “or a ring-fencing transfer scheme”.
After section 106A insert—

P2para.Text: A scheme is a ring-fencing transfer scheme if it—

P3para.Text: is one under which the whole or part of the business carried on—

P4para.Text: by a UK authorised person, or
by a qualifying body,

P3para.Text: is to be transferred to another body (“the transferee”),
is to be made for one or more of the purposes mentioned in subsection (3), and
is not an excluded scheme or an insurance business transfer scheme.

P2para.Text: “Qualifying body” means a body which—

P3para.Text: is incorporated in the United Kingdom,
is a member of the group of a UK authorised person, and
is not itself an authorised person.

P2para.Text: The purposes are—

P3para.Text: enabling a UK authorised person to carry on core activities as a ring-fenced body in compliance with the ring-fencing provisions;
enabling the transferee to carry on core activities as a ring-fenced body in compliance with the ring-fencing provisions;

making provision in connection with the implementation of proposals that would involve a body corporate whose group includes the body corporate to whose business the scheme relates becoming a ring-fenced body while one or more other members of its group are not ring-fenced bodies;

making provision in connection with the implementation of proposals that would involve a body corporate whose group includes the transferee becoming a ring-fenced body while one or more other members of the transferee’s group are not ring-fenced bodies.

P2para.Text: A scheme is an excluded scheme for the purposes of this section if—

P3para.Text: the body to whose business the scheme relates is a building society or credit union, or
the scheme is a compromise or arrangement to which Part 27 of the Companies Act 2006 (mergers and divisions of public companies) applies.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1)(a) it is immaterial whether or not the business to be transferred is carried on in the United Kingdom.
“UK authorised person” has the same meaning as in section 105.
“Building society” and “credit union” have the same meanings as in section 106.
“The ring-fencing provisions” means ring-fencing rules and the duty imposed as a result of section 142G.
Section 107 (application for order sanctioning transfer scheme) is amended as follows.
In subsection (1), for “or a reclaim fund business transfer scheme” substitute “, a reclaim fund business transfer scheme or a ring-fencing transfer scheme”.
After subsection (2) insert—
An application relating to a ring-fencing transfer scheme may be made only with the consent of the PRA.
In deciding whether to give consent, the PRA must have regard to the scheme report prepared under section 109A in relation to the ring-fencing transfer scheme.

P1para.Text: For the heading to section 109 substitute “Scheme reports: insurance business transfer schemes”.
After section 109 insert—

P2para.Text: An application under section 106B in respect of a ring-fencing transfer scheme must be accompanied by a report on the terms of the scheme (a “scheme report”).
A scheme report may be made only by a person—

P3para.Text: appearing to the PRA to have the skills necessary to enable the person to make a proper report, and
nominated or approved for the purpose by the PRA.

P2para.Text: A scheme report must be made in a form approved by the PRA.
A scheme report must state—

P3para.Text: whether persons other than the transferor concerned are likely to be adversely affected by the scheme, and
if so, whether the adverse effect is likely to be greater than is reasonably necessary in order to achieve whichever of the purposes mentioned in section 106B(3) is relevant.

P2para.Text: The PRA must consult the FCA before—

P3para.Text: nominating or approving a person under subsection (2)(b), or
approving a form under subsection (3).

P2para.Text: Section 110 (right to participate in proceedings) is amended as follows.
In subsection (1), after “section 107” insert “relating to an insurance business transfer scheme, a banking business transfer scheme or a reclaim fund business transfer scheme”.
After subsection (2) insert—
Subsections (4) and (5) apply where an application under section 107 relates to a ring-fencing transfer scheme.
The following are also entitled to be heard—

P3para.Text: the PRA,
where the transferee is an authorised person, the FCA, and
any person (“P”) (including an employee of the transferor concerned or of the transferee) who alleges that P would be adversely affected by the carrying out of the scheme.

P2para.Text: P is not entitled to be heard by virtue of subsection (4)(c) unless before the hearing P has—

P3para.Text: filed (in Scotland, lodged) with the court a written statement of the representations that P wishes the court to consider, and
served copies of the statement on the PRA and the transferor concerned.

P2para.Text: Section 111 (sanction of court for business transfer schemes) is amended as follows.
In subsection (1), for “or a reclaim fund business transfer scheme” substitute “, a reclaim fund business transfer scheme or a ring-fencing transfer scheme”.
In subsection (2), after paragraph (aa) insert—

P3para.Text: in the case of a ring-fencing transfer scheme, the appropriate certificates have been obtained (as to which see Part 2B of that Schedule);

P1para.Text: In section 112 (effect of order sanctioning business transfer scheme), in subsection (10), after “transfer scheme” insert “or ring-fencing transfer scheme”.
In section 112A (rights to terminate etc.), in subsection (1), for “or a banking business transfer scheme” substitute “, a banking business transfer scheme or a ring-fencing transfer scheme”.
In Schedule 12 (transfer schemes: certificates) after Part 2A insert—

P2para.Text: For the purposes of section 111(2) the appropriate certificates, in relation to a ring-fencing transfer scheme, are—

P3para.Text: a certificate given by the PRA certifying its approval of the application,
a certificate under paragraph 9C, and
if sub-paragraph (2) applies, a certificate under paragraph 9D.

P2para.Text: This sub-paragraph applies if the transferee is an EEA firm falling within paragraph 5(a) or (b) of Schedule 3.

A certificate under this paragraph is one given by the relevant authority and certifying that, taking the proposed transfer into account, the transferee possesses, or will possess before the scheme takes effect, adequate financial resources.
“Relevant authority” means—

P3para.Text: if the transferee is a PRA-authorised person with a Part 4A permission or with permission under Schedule 4, the PRA;
if the transferee is an EEA firm falling within paragraph 5(a) or (b) of Schedule 3, its home state regulator;

if the transferee does not fall within paragraph (a) or (b) but is subject to regulation in a country or territory outside the United Kingdom, the authority responsible for the supervision of the transferee’s business in the place in which the transferee has its head office;
in any other case, the FCA.

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (2), any reference to a transferee of a particular description includes a reference to a transferee who will be of that description if the proposed ring-fencing transfer scheme takes effect.

P1group.Title: Certificate as to consent of home state regulator

P1para.Text: A certificate under this paragraph is one given by the appropriate regulator and certifying that the home state regulator of the transferee has been notified of the proposed scheme and that—

P3para.Text: the home state regulator has responded to the notification, or
the period of 3 months beginning with the notification has elapsed.

P1para.Text: The Banking Act 2009 is amended as follows.
After section 12 insert—

P2para.Text: The third stabilisation option is exercised by the use of the power in subsection (2).
The Bank of England may make one or more resolution instruments (which may contain provision or proposals of any kind mentioned in subsections (3) to (6)).
A resolution instrument may—

P3para.Text: make special bail-in provision with respect to a specified bank;
make other provision for the purposes of, or in connection with, any special bail-in provision made by that or another instrument.

P2para.Text: A resolution instrument may—

P3para.Text: provide for securities issued by a specified bank to be transferred to a bail-in administrator (see section 12B) or another person;

make other provision for the purposes of, or in connection with, the transfer of securities issued by a specified bank (whether or not the transfer has been or is to be effected by that instrument, by another resolution instrument or otherwise).

P2para.Text: A resolution instrument may set out proposals with regard to the future ownership of a specified bank or of the business of a specified bank, and any other proposals (for example, proposals about making special bail-in provision) that the Bank of England may think appropriate.
A resolution instrument may make any other provision the Bank of England may think it appropriate to make in exercise of specific powers under this Part.
Provision made in accordance with subsection (4) may relate to—

P3para.Text: specified securities, or
securities of a specified description.

P2para.Text: Where the Bank of England has exercised the power in subsection (4) to transfer securities to a bail-in administrator, the Bank of England must exercise its functions under this Part (see, in particular, section 48V) with a view to ensuring that any securities held by a person in the capacity of a bail-in administrator are so held only for so long as is, in the Bank of England’s opinion, appropriate having regard to the special resolution objectives.
References in this Part to “special bail-in provision” are to provision made in reliance on section 48B.
The Bank of England may, in a resolution instrument, appoint an individual or body corporate as a bail-in administrator.
A bail-in administrator is appointed—

P3para.Text: to hold any securities that may be transferred or issued to that person in the capacity of bail-in administrator;
to perform any other functions that may be conferred under any provision of this Part.

P2para.Text: The Bank of England may appoint more than one bail-in administrator to perform functions in relation to a bank (but no more than one of them may at any one time be authorised to hold securities as mentioned in subsection (2)(a)).

Securities held by a bail-in administrator (in that capacity, and whether as a result of a resolution instrument or otherwise) are to be held in accordance with the terms of a resolution instrument that transfers those, or other, securities to the bail-in administrator.
For example, the following provision may be made by virtue of subsection (4)—

P3para.Text: provision that specified rights of a bail-in administrator with respect to all or any of the securities are to be exercisable only as directed by the Bank of England;
provision specifying rights or obligations that the bail-in administrator is, or is not, to have in relation to some or all of the securities.

P2para.Text: A bail-in administrator must have regard, in performing any functions of the office, to any objectives that may be specified in a resolution instrument.

Where one or more objectives are specified in accordance with subsection (6), the objectives are to be taken to have equal status with each other, unless the contrary is stated in the resolution instrument.
See sections 48I to 48K for further provision about bail-in administrators.

P1para.Text: After section 8 insert—

P2para.Text: The Bank of England may exercise a stabilisation power in respect of a bank in accordance with section 12A(2) only if satisfied that the condition in subsection (2) is met.
The condition is that the exercise of the power is necessary, having regard to the public interest in—

P3para.Text: the stability of the financial systems of the United Kingdom,
the maintenance of public confidence in the stability of those systems,
the protection of depositors, or
the protection of any client assets that may be affected.

P2para.Text: Before determining whether that condition is met, and if so how to react, the Bank of England must consult—

P3para.Text: the PRA,
the FCA, and
the Treasury.

P2para.Text: The condition in this section is in addition to the conditions in section 7.

P1group.Title: Further provision about the bail-in option

P1para.Text: After section 48A insert—

P2para.Text: “Special bail-in provision”, in relation to a bank, means any of the following (or any combination of the following)—

P3para.Text: provision cancelling a liability owed by the bank;
provision modifying, or changing the form of, a liability owed by the bank;
provision that a contract under which the bank has a liability is to have effect as if a specified right had been exercised under it.

P2para.Text: A power to make special bail-in provision—

P3para.Text: may be exercised only for the purpose of, or in connection with, reducing, deferring or cancelling a liability of the bank;
may not be exercised so as to affect any excluded liability.

P2para.Text: The following rules apply to the interpretation of subsection (1).
1. The reference to cancelling a liability owed by the bank includes a reference to cancelling a contract under which the bank has a liability.
2. The reference to modifying a liability owed by the bank includes a reference to modifying the terms (or the effect of the terms) of a contract under which the bank has a liability.
3. The reference to changing the form of a liability owed by the bank, includes, for example—

Para.Text: converting an instrument under which the bank owes a liability from one form or class to another,
replacing such an instrument with another instrument of a different form or class, or
creating a new security (of any form or class) in connection with the modification of such an instrument.

P2para.Text: Examples of special bail-in provision include—

P3para.Text: provision that transactions or events of any specified kind have or do not have (directly or indirectly) specified consequences or are to be treated in a specified manner for specified purposes;
provision discharging persons from further performance of obligations under a contract and dealing with the consequences of persons being so discharged.

P2para.Text: The form and class of the instrument (“the resulting instrument”) into which an instrument is converted, or with which it is replaced, do not matter for the purposes of paragraphs (a) and (b) of rule 3 in subsection (3); for instance, the resulting instrument may (if it is a security) fall within Class 1 or any other Class in section 14.
The following liabilities of the bank are “excluded liabilities”—

P3para.Text: liabilities representing protected deposits;
any liability, so far as it is secured;
liabilities that the bank has by virtue of holding client assets;
liabilities with an original maturity of less than 7 days owed by the bank to a credit institution or investment firm;
liabilities arising from participation in designated settlement systems and owed to such systems or to operators of, or participants in, such systems;

liabilities owed to central counterparties recognised by the European Securities and Markets Authority in accordance with Article 25 of Regulation (EU) 648/2012 of the European Parliament and the Council;
liabilities owed to an employee or former employee in relation to salary or other remuneration, except variable remuneration;
liabilities owed to an employee or former employee in relation to rights under a pension scheme, except rights to discretionary benefits;
liabilities owed to creditors arising from the provision to the bank of goods or services (other than financial services) that are critical to the daily functioning of the bank’s operations.

P2para.Text: The following special rules apply in cases involving banking group companies—

P3para.Text: a liability mentioned in subsection (6)(d) is not an excluded liability if the credit institution or investment firm to which the liability is owed is a banking group company in relation to the bank (see section 81D);
in subsection (6)(i) the reference to creditors does not include companies which are banking group companies in relation to the bank.

P2para.Text: A deposit is “protected” so far as it is covered by the Financial Services Compensation Scheme.
A deposit is “protected” so far as it is covered by a scheme which—

P3para.Text: operates outside the United Kingdom, and
is comparable to the Financial Services Compensation Scheme.

P2para.Text: If one or both of subsections (1) and (2) apply to a deposit, the amount of the deposit “protected” is the highest amount which results from either of those subsections.

In subsections (1) and (2) and section 48B(6)(a), “deposit” has the meaning given by article 5(2) of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (Regulated Activities) Order 2001 (S.I. 2001/544), but ignoring the exclusions in article 6.
In section 48B—

Para.Text: “client assets” means assets which the bank has undertaken to hold on trust for, or on behalf of, a client;
“contract” includes any instrument;

“credit institution” means any credit institution as defined in Article 4.1(1) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council, other than an entity mentioned in Article 2.5(2) to (23) of Directive 2013/36/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council;
“designated settlement system” means a system designated in accordance with Directive 98/26/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council (as amended by Directives 2009/44/EC and 2010/78/EU);
“employee” includes the holder of an office;

“investment firm” means an investment firm as defined in Article 4.1(2) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council that is subject to the initial capital requirement specified in Article 28(2) of Directive 2013/36/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council;
“pension scheme” includes any arrangement for the payment of pensions, allowances and gratuities;
“secured” means secured against property or rights, or otherwise covered by collateral arrangements.

P2para.Text: In subsection (1)—

Para.Text: “assets” has the same meaning as in section 232(4) (ignoring for these purposes section 232(5A)(b));
“collateral arrangements” includes arrangements which are title transfer collateral arrangements for the purposes of section 48.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of section 48B(6)(h), a benefit under a pension scheme is discretionary so far as the employee’s right to the benefit was a result of the exercise of a discretion.
This section applies where the Bank of England makes a resolution instrument containing special bail-in provision (see section 48B(1)).
The Bank of England must report to the Chancellor of the Exchequer stating the reasons why that provision has been made in the case of the liabilities concerned.
If the provision departs from the insolvency treatment principles, the report must state the reasons why it does so.
The insolvency treatment principles are that where an instrument includes special bail-in provision—

P3para.Text: the provision made by the instrument must be consistent with treating all the liabilities of the bank in accordance with the priority they would enjoy on a liquidation, and
any creditors who would have equal priority on a liquidation are to bear losses on an equal footing with each other.

P2para.Text: A report must comply with any other requirements as to content that may be specified by the Treasury.
A report must be made as soon as reasonably practicable after the making of the resolution instrument to which it relates.
The Chancellor of the Exchequer must lay a copy of each report under subsection (2) before Parliament.

P1group.Title: Power to amend definition of “excluded liabilities”

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by order amend section 48B(6) by—

P3para.Text: adding to the list of excluded liabilities;
amending or omitting any paragraph of that subsection, other than paragraphs (a) to (c).

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by order amend section 48C or 48D.
The powers conferred by subsections (1) and (2) include power to make consequential and transitional provision.
An order under this section—

P3para.Text: must be made by statutory instrument, and
may not be made unless a draft has been laid before and approved by resolution of each House of Parliament.

P2para.Text: The Treasury must consult before laying a draft order under this section before Parliament.

The Treasury may, for the purpose of ensuring that the treatment of liabilities in any instrument that contains special bail-in provision is aligned to an appropriate degree with the treatment of liabilities on an insolvency, by order specify matters or principles to which the Bank of England is to be required to have regard in making any such instrument.
An order may, for example, specify the insolvency treatment principles (as defined in section 48E(4)) or alternative principles.
An order may specify the meaning of “insolvency” for one or more purposes of the order.
An order may amend sections 44C(4) and 48E(4).
An order —

P3para.Text: is to be made by statutory instrument, and
may not be made unless a draft has been laid before and approved by resolution of each House of Parliament.

P2para.Text: A resolution instrument may require a bail-in administrator, or one or more directors of the bank, to—

P3para.Text: draw up a business reorganisation plan with respect to the bank, and
submit it to the Bank of England within the period allowed by (or under) the instrument.

P2para.Text: “Business reorganisation plan” means a plan that includes—

P3para.Text: an assessment of the factors that caused Condition 1 in section 7 to be met in the case of the bank,
a description of the measures to be adopted with a view to restoring the viability of the bank, and
a timetable for the implementation of those measures.

P2para.Text: Where a person has submitted a business reorganisation plan to the Bank of England under subsection (1) (or has re-submitted a plan under subsection (4)), the Bank of England—

P3para.Text: must approve the plan if satisfied that the plan is appropriately designed for meeting the objective mentioned in subsection (2)(b);
must otherwise require the person to amend the plan in a specified manner.

P2para.Text: Where the Bank of England has required a person to amend a business re-organisation plan, the person must re-submit the amended plan within the period allowed by (or under) the resolution instrument.
Before deciding what action to take under subsection (3) the Bank of England must (for each submission or re-submission of a plan) consult—

P3para.Text: the PRA, and
the FCA.

P2para.Text: A business reorganisation plan may include recommendations by the person submitting the plan as to the exercise by the Bank of England of any of its powers under this Part in relation to the bank.
Where a resolution instrument contains provision under subsection (1), the instrument may—

P3para.Text: specify further matters (in addition to those mentioned in subsection (2)) that must be dealt with in the business reorganisation plan;
make provision about the timing of actions to be taken in connection with the making and approval of the plan;

enable any provision that the Bank of England has power under paragraph (a) or (b) to make in the instrument to be made instead in an agreement between the Bank of England and the bail-in administrator.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of subsection (2)(b) the viability of a bank is to be assessed by reference to whether the bank satisfies, and (if so) for how long it may be expected to continue to satisfy, the threshold conditions (as defined in section 55B of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000).
A resolution instrument may—

P3para.Text: authorise a bail-in administrator to manage the bank’s business (or confer on a bail-in administrator any other power with respect to the management of the bank’s business);
authorise a bail-in administrator to exercise any other powers of the bank;
confer on a bail-in administrator any other power the Bank of England may consider appropriate;
