provide that the exercise of any power conferred by the instrument in accordance with this section is to be subject to conditions specified in the instrument.

P2para.Text: A resolution instrument may require a bail-in administrator to make reports to the Bank of England—

P3para.Text: on any matter specified in the instrument, and
at the times or intervals specified in the instrument.

P2para.Text: If a resolution instrument specifies a matter in accordance with subsection (2)(a), it may provide for further requirements as to the contents of the report on that matter to be specified in an agreement between the Bank of England and the bail-in administrator.
A resolution instrument may—

P3para.Text: require a bail-in administrator to consult specified persons before exercising specified functions (and may specify particular matters on which the specified person must be consulted);
provide that a bail-in administrator is not to exercise specified functions without the consent of a specified person.

P2para.Text: A bail-in administrator may do anything necessary or desirable for the purposes of or in connection with the performance of the functions of the office.
A bail-in administrator is not a servant or agent of the Crown (and, in particular, is not a civil servant).
Where a bail-in administrator is appointed under this Part, the Bank of England—

P3para.Text: must make provision in a resolution instrument for resignation and replacement of the bail-in administrator;

may remove the bail-in administrator from office only (i) on the ground of incapacity or misconduct, or (ii) on the ground that there is no further need for a person to perform the functions conferred on the bail-in administrator.

P2para.Text: A resolution instrument may provide for the payment of remuneration and allowances to a bail-in administrator.
Provision made under subsection (1) may provide that the amounts are—

P3para.Text: to be paid by the Bank of England, or
to be determined by the Bank of England and paid by the bank.

P2para.Text: A bail-in administrator is not liable for damages in respect of anything done in good faith for the purposes of or in connection with the functions of the office (subject to section 8 of the Human Rights Act 1998).
A resolution instrument may—

P3para.Text: cancel or modify any securities to which this subsection applies;
convert any such securities from one form or class into another.

P2para.Text: Subsection (1) applies to securities issued by the bank that fall within Class 1 in section 14.
A resolution instrument may—

P3para.Text: make provision with respect to rights attaching to securities issued by the bank;
provide for the listing of securities issued by the bank to be discontinued.

P2para.Text: The reference in subsection (1)(b) to converting securities from one form or class into another includes creating a new security in connection with the modification of an existing security.
The provision that may be made under subsection (3)(a) includes, for example—

P3para.Text: provision that specified rights attaching to securities are to be treated as having been exercised;
provision that the Bank of England, or a bail-in administrator, is to be treated as authorised to exercise specified rights attaching to securities;
provision that specified rights attaching to securities may not be exercised for a period specified in the instrument.

P2para.Text: In subsection (3)(b) the reference to “listing” is to listing under section 74 of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000.
The provision that may be made under this section in relation to any securities is in addition to any provision that the Bank of England may have power to make in relation to them under section 48B.
In this section “default event provision” has the same meaning as in section 22.
A resolution instrument may provide for subsection (3) or (4) to apply (but need not apply either).
If this subsection applies, the resolution instrument is to be disregarded in determining whether a default event provision applies.
If this subsection applies, the resolution instrument is to be disregarded in determining whether a default event provision applies except so far as the instrument provides otherwise.
In subsections (3) and (4) a reference to the resolution instrument is a reference to—

P3para.Text: the making of the instrument,
anything that is done by the instrument or is to be, or may be, done under or by virtue of the instrument, and
any action or decision taken or made under this or another enactment in so far as it resulted in, or was connected to, the making of the instrument.

P2para.Text: Provision under subsection (2) may apply subsection (3) or (4)—

P3para.Text: generally or only for specified purposes, cases or circumstances, or
differently for different purposes, cases or circumstances.

P2para.Text: A thing is not done by virtue of a resolution instrument for the purposes of subsection (5)(b) merely by virtue of being done under a contract or other agreement rights or obligations under which have been affected by the instrument.
A resolution instrument may enable the Bank of England—

P3para.Text: to remove a director of a specified bank;
to vary the service contract of a director of a specified bank;
to terminate the service contract of a director of a specified bank;
to appoint a director of a specified bank.

P2para.Text: Subsection (1) also applies to a director of any undertaking which is a banking group company in respect of a specified bank.
Appointments under subsection (1)(d) are to be on terms and conditions agreed with the Bank of England.

P1group.Title: Directions in or under resolution instrument

P2para.Text: A resolution instrument may—

P3para.Text: require one or more directors of the bank to comply with any general or specific directions that may be set out in the instrument;
enable the Bank of England to give written directions (whether general or specific) to one or more directors of the bank.

P2para.Text: A director—

P3para.Text: is not to be regarded as failing to comply with any duty owed to any person (for example, a shareholder, creditor or employee of the bank) by virtue of any action or inaction in compliance with a direction given under subsection (1)(a) or (b);
is to be immune from liability in damages in respect of action or inaction in accordance with a direction.

P2para.Text: A director must comply with a direction within the period of time specified in the direction, or if no period of time is specified, as soon as reasonably practicable.

A direction under subsection (1)(a) or (b) is enforceable on an application made by the Bank of England, by injunction or, in Scotland, by an order for specific performance under section 45 of the Court of Session Act 1988.

P1group.Title: Orders for safeguarding certain financial arrangements

P2para.Text: In this section “protected arrangements” means security interests, title transfer collateral arrangements, set-off arrangements and netting arrangements.
In subsection (1)—

Para.Text: “netting arrangements” means arrangements under which a number of claims or obligations can be converted into a net claim or obligation, and includes, in particular, “close-out” netting arrangements, under which actual or theoretical debts are calculated during the course of a contract for the purpose of enabling them to be set off against each other or to be converted into a net debt;
“security interests” means arrangements under which one person acquires, by way of security, an actual or contingent interest in the property of another;
“set-off arrangements” means arrangements under which two or more debts, claims or obligations can be set off against each other;

“title transfer collateral arrangements” means arrangements under which Person 1 transfers assets to Person 2 on terms providing for Person 2 to transfer assets if specified obligations are discharged.

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by order—

P3para.Text: restrict the exercise of any power within the scope of this paragraph in cases that involve, or where the exercise of the power might affect, protected arrangements;
impose conditions on the exercise of any power within the scope of this paragraph in cases that involve, or where the exercise of the power might affect, protected arrangements;
require any instrument that makes special bail-in provision to include specified provision, or provision to a specified effect, in respect of or for purposes connected with protected arrangements;

provide for an instrument to be void or voidable, or for other consequences to arise, if or in so far as the instrument is made or purported to be made in contravention of a provision of the order (or of another order under this section);
specify principles to which the Bank of England is to be required to have regard in exercising specified powers—

P4para.Text: that involve protected arrangements, or
where the exercise of the powers might affect protected arrangements.

P2para.Text: References to exercising a power within the scope of paragraph (a) or (b) of subsection (3) are to making an instrument containing provision made in reliance on section 12A(3)(a) or 44B (special bail-in provision).
An order may apply to protected arrangements generally or only to arrangements—

P3para.Text: of a specified kind, or
made or applying in specified circumstances.

P2para.Text: An order may include provision for determining which arrangements are to be, or not to be, treated as protected arrangements; in particular, an order may provide for arrangements to be classified not according to their description by the parties but according to one or more indications of how they are treated, or are intended to be treated, in commercial practice.
In this section “arrangements” includes arrangements which—

P3para.Text: are formed wholly or partly by one or more contracts or trusts;
arise under or are wholly or partly governed by the law of a country or territory outside the United Kingdom;
wholly or partly arise automatically as a matter of law;
involve any number of parties;
operate partly by reference to other arrangements between parties.

P2para.Text: An order —

P3para.Text: is to be made by statutory instrument, and
may not be made unless a draft has been laid before and approved by resolution of each House of Parliament.

P2para.Text: A resolution instrument may provide for anything (including legal proceedings) that relates to anything affected by the instrument and is in the process of being done immediately before the instrument takes effect to be continued from the time the instrument takes effect.
A resolution instrument may modify references (express or implied) in an instrument or document.

A resolution instrument may require or permit any person to provide information and assistance to the Bank of England or another person, for the purposes of or in connection with provision made or to be made in that or another resolution instrument.

P1group.Title: Execution and registration of instruments etc

P2para.Text: A resolution instrument (other than an instrument that provides for securities to be transferred) may permit or require the execution, issue or delivery of an instrument.
A resolution instrument may provide for any provision in the instrument to have effect irrespective of—

P3para.Text: whether an instrument has been produced, delivered, transferred or otherwise dealt with;
registration.

P2para.Text: A resolution instrument may provide for the effect of an instrument executed, issued or delivered in accordance with the resolution instrument.
A resolution instrument may—

P3para.Text: entitle a person to be registered in respect of a security;
require a person to effect registration.

P2para.Text: Provision made in a resolution instrument takes effect despite any restriction arising by virtue of contract or legislation or in any other way.
A resolution instrument may include incidental, consequential or transitional provision.
In relying on subsection (2) a resolution instrument—

P3para.Text: may make provision generally or only for specified purposes, cases or circumstances, and
may make different provision for different purposes, cases or circumstances.

P2para.Text: As soon as is reasonably practicable after making a resolution instrument in respect of a bank the Bank of England must send a copy to—

P3para.Text: the bank,
the Treasury,
the PRA,
the FCA, and
any other person specified in the code of practice under section 5.

P2para.Text: As soon as is reasonably practicable after making a resolution instrument the Bank of England must publish a copy—

P3para.Text: on the Bank’s internet website, and
in two newspapers, chosen by the Bank of England to maximise the likelihood of the instrument coming to the attention of persons likely to be affected.

P2para.Text: Where the Treasury receive a copy of a resolution instrument under subsection (1) they must lay a copy before Parliament.
This section applies where the Bank of England has made a resolution instrument (“the original instrument”) with respect to a bank.
The Bank of England may make, with respect to the bank, one or more resolution instruments designated by the Bank of England as supplemental resolution instruments.

Sections 7 and 8A do not apply to a supplemental resolution instrument (but it is to be treated in the same way as a resolution instrument for all other purposes, including for the purposes of the application of a power under this Part).
Before making a supplemental resolution instrument the Bank of England must consult—

P3para.Text: the PRA,
the FCA, and
the Treasury.

P2para.Text: The possibility of making a supplemental resolution instrument in reliance on subsection (2) is without prejudice to the possibility of making a new instrument in accordance with section 12A(2) (and not in reliance on subsection (2) above).
This section applies where the Bank of England has made a resolution instrument (“the original instrument”) providing for securities issued by a specified bank to be transferred to any person.
The Bank of England may make one or more onward transfer resolution instruments.
An onward transfer resolution instrument is a resolution instrument which—

P3para.Text: provides for the transfer of—

P4para.Text: securities which were issued by the bank before the original instrument and have been transferred by the
original instrument or a supplemental resolution instrument, or
securities which were issued by the bank after the original instrument;

P3para.Text: makes other provision for the purposes of, or in connection with, the transfer of securities issued by the bank (whether the transfer has been or is to be effected by that instrument, by another instrument or otherwise).

P2para.Text: An onward transfer resolution instrument may not transfer securities to the transferor under the original instrument.

Sections 7 and 8A do not apply to an onward transfer resolution instrument (but it is to be treated in the same way as any other resolution instrument for all other purposes, including for the purposes of the application of a power under this Part).
Before making an onward transfer resolution instrument the Bank of England must consult—

P3para.Text: the PRA,
the FCA, and
the Treasury.

P2para.Text: Section 48U applies where the Bank of England has made an onward transfer resolution instrument.
This section applies where the Bank of England has made an instrument (“the original instrument”) that is either—

P3para.Text: a resolution instrument providing for the transfer of securities issued by a bank to a person (“the transferee”), or
an onward transfer resolution instrument (see section 48V) providing for the transfer of securities issued by a bank to a person (“the onward transferee”).

P2para.Text: In a case falling within subsection (1)(a) the Bank of England may make one or more reverse transfer resolution instruments in respect of securities issued by the bank and held by the transferee (whether or not they were transferred by the original instrument).

In a case falling within subsection (1)(b), the Bank of England may make one or more reverse transfer resolution instruments in respect of securities issued by the bank and held by the onward transferee.
A reverse transfer resolution instrument is a resolution instrument which—

P3para.Text: provides for transfer to the transferor under the original instrument;
makes other provision for the purposes of, or in connection with, the transfer of securities which are, or could be or could have been, transferred under paragraph (a).

P2para.Text: Except where subsection (6) applies, the Bank of England may make a reverse transfer resolution instrument under subsection (2) only with the written consent of the transferee.
This subsection applies where the transferee is—

P3para.Text: a bail-in administrator, or
a person who is not to be authorised to exercise any rights attaching to the securities except on the Bank of England’s instructions.

P2para.Text: The Bank of England may make a reverse transfer resolution instrument under subsection (3) only with the written consent of the onward transferee.

Sections 7 and 8A do not apply to a reverse transfer resolution instrument (but it is to be treated in the same way as any other resolution instrument for all other purposes including for the purposes of an application of a power under this Part).
Before making a reverse transfer resolution instrument the Bank of England must consult—

P3para.Text: the PRA,
the FCA, and
the Treasury.

P2para.Text: Section 48U applies where the Bank of England has made a reverse transfer resolution instrument.
After section 41 insert—

P1group.Title: Transfer of property subsequent to resolution instrument

P2para.Text: This section applies where the Bank of England has made a resolution instrument.
The Bank of England may make one or more property transfer instruments in respect of property, rights or liabilities of the bank.
Sections 7 and 8A do not apply to a property transfer instrument under subsection (2).
Before making a property transfer instrument under subsection (2) the Bank of England must consult—

P3para.Text: the PRA,
the FCA, and
the Treasury.

P2para.Text: In section 42 (supplemental property transfer instruments)—

P3para.Text: in subsection (1) for “12(2)” substitute “12(2) or 41A(2)”;
in subsection (4) for “and 8” substitute “, 8 and 8A”;
in subsection (6) for “or 12(2)” substitute “, 12(2) or 41A(2)”.

P2para.Text: After section 44 insert—
This section applies where the Bank of England has made a property transfer instrument in accordance with section 41A(2) (“the original instrument”).
The Bank of England may make one or more bail-in reverse property transfer instruments in respect of property, rights or liabilities of the transferee under the original instrument.
A bail-in reverse property transfer instrument is a property transfer instrument which—

P3para.Text: provides for a transfer to the transferor under the original instrument;

makes other provision for the purposes of, or in connection with, the transfer of property, rights or liabilities which are, or could be or could have been, transferred under paragraph (a) (whether the transfer has been or is to be effected by that instrument or otherwise).

P2para.Text: The Bank of England may make a bail-in reverse property transfer instrument only with the written consent of the transferee under the original instrument.

Sections 7 and 8A do not apply to a bail-in reverse property transfer instrument (but it is to be treated in the same way as any other property transfer instrument for all other purposes, including for the purposes of the application of a power under this Part).
Before making a bail-in reverse property transfer instrument the Bank of England must consult—

P3para.Text: the PRA,
the FCA, and
the Treasury.

P2para.Text: Section 42 (supplemental instruments) applies where the Bank of England has made a bail-in reverse property transfer instrument.

P1group.Title: Property transfer instruments: special bail-in provision

P2para.Text: A property transfer instrument under section 12(2) or 41A(2) may make special bail-in provision with respect to the bank (see section 48B).

In the case of a property transfer instrument under section 12(2), the power under subsection (1) to make the provision described in section 48B(1)(b) (see also rule 3(a) and (b) of section 48B(3)) includes power to make provision replacing a liability (of any form) of the bank mentioned in subsection (1) with a security (of any form or class) of the bridge bank mentioned in section 12(1).

Where securities of the bridge bank (“B”) are, as a result of subsection (2), held by a person other than the Bank of England, that does not prevent B from being regarded for the purposes of this Part (see particularly section 12(1)) as being wholly owned by the Bank of England, as long as the Bank of England continues to hold all the ordinary shares issued by B.
This section applies where the Bank of England makes a property transfer instrument containing provision made in reliance on section 44B.
The Bank of England must report to the Chancellor of the Exchequer stating the reasons why that provision was made in the case of the liabilities concerned.
If the provision departs from the insolvency treatment principles, the report must state the reasons why it does so.
The insolvency treatment principles are that where an instrument includes special bail-in provision—

P3para.Text: the provision made by the instrument must be consistent with treating all the liabilities of the bank in accordance with the priority they would enjoy on a liquidation, and
any creditors who would have equal priority on a liquidation are to bear losses on an equal footing with each other.

P2para.Text: A report must comply with any other requirements as to content that may be specified by the Treasury.
A report must be made as soon as reasonably practicable after the making of the property transfer instrument to which it relates.
The Chancellor of the Exchequer must lay a copy of each report under subsection (2) before Parliament.
In section 48A (creation of liabilities), in subsection (1), after “44(4)(c)” insert “, 44A(3)(b)”.
In section 49 (orders)—

P3para.Text: in subsection (1), for “three” substitute “four” and for “and property transfer instruments” substitute “, property transfer instruments and orders and resolution instruments”;
after subsection (2) insert—

P2para.Text: A “bail-in compensation order” is an order establishing a scheme for determining, in accordance with section 52A, whether any transferors or others should be paid compensation.
After section 52 insert—
Subsection (2) applies if the Bank of England makes—

P3para.Text: a resolution instrument under section 12A(2),
a property transfer instrument under section 41A(2), or
a supplemental resolution instrument under section 48U(2).

P2para.Text: The Treasury must make a bail-in compensation order (see section 49(2A)).
A bail-in compensation order may include provision for—

P3para.Text: an independent valuer (in which case sections 54 to 56 are to apply);
valuation principles (in which case section 57(2) to (5) is to apply).

P2para.Text: In section 53 (onward and reverse transfers), in subsection (1)—

P3para.Text: after paragraph (f) insert—
the Bank of England makes a reverse property transfer instrument under section 44A(2),
the Bank of England makes a supplemental property transfer instrument by virtue of section 44A(7),
omit the “or” after paragraph (g);
after paragraph (h) insert—
the Bank of England makes an onward transfer resolution instrument under section 48V(2),
the Bank of England makes a reverse transfer resolution instrument under section 48W(2) or (3), or
the Bank of England makes a supplemental resolution instrument by virtue of section 48V(7) or 48W(10).

P2para.Text: In section 54 (independent valuer)—

P3para.Text: in subsection (1), after “compensation scheme order” insert “or bail-in compensation order”;
in subsection (4)(b), after “order” insert “or bail-in compensation order”.

P2para.Text: In section 56 (independent valuer: money), in subsection (2)(b) for “or third party compensation order” substitute “, third party compensation order or bail-in compensation order”.
In section 57 (valuation principles), in subsection (1), after “order” insert “or bail-in compensation order”.
After section 60 insert—
The Treasury may make regulations about compensation arrangements in the case of—

P3para.Text: resolution instruments under section 12A(2) and supplemental resolution instruments under section 48U(2), and
instruments (made under any provision) that include special bail-in provision.

P2para.Text: Regulations may—

P3para.Text: require a compensation scheme order, a third party compensation order or a bail-in compensation order to include provision of a specified kind or to specified effect;
make provision that is to be treated as forming part of any such order (whether (i) generally, (ii) only if applied, (iii) unless disapplied, or (iv) subject to express modification).

P2para.Text: Regulations may provide for whether compensation is to be paid, and if so what amount is to be paid, to be determined by reference to any factors or combination of factors; in particular, the regulations may provide for entitlement—

P3para.Text: to be contingent upon the occurrence or non-occurrence of specified events;
to be determined wholly or partly by an independent valuer (within the meaning of sections 54 to 56) appointed in accordance with a compensation scheme order or bail-in compensation order.

P2para.Text: Regulations may make provision about payment including, in particular, provision for payments—

P3para.Text: on account subject to terms and conditions;
by instalment.

P2para.Text: Regulations—

P3para.Text: are to be made by statutory instrument, and
may not be made unless a draft has been laid before and approved by resolution of each House of Parliament.

P1group.Title: Principle of no less favourable treatment

P2para.Text: In making regulations under section 60A the Treasury must, in particular, have regard to the desirability of ensuring that pre-resolution shareholders and creditors of a bank do not receive less favourable treatment than they would have received had the bank entered insolvency immediately before the coming into effect of the initial instrument.
References in this section to the initial instrument are—

P3para.Text: in relation to compensation arrangements in the case of property transfer instruments under section 12(2), to the first instrument to be made under that provision with respect to the bank;
in relation to compensation arrangements in other cases, to the first resolution instrument to be made under section 12A with respect to the bank.

P2para.Text: The “pre-resolution shareholders and creditors” of a bank are the persons who held securities issued by the bank, or were creditors of the bank, immediately before the coming into effect of the initial instrument.

References in this section to insolvency include a reference to (i) liquidation, (ii) bank insolvency, (iii) administration, (iv) bank administration, (v) receivership, (vi) composition with creditors, and (vii) a scheme of arrangement.
In section 61(1) (sources of compensation),—

P3para.Text: omit the “and” at the end of paragraph (c);
after paragraph (c) insert—
bail-in compensation orders,
after paragraph (d) insert, “, and
regulations under section 60A.

P2para.Text: In section 62(1) (procedure), omit the “and” at the end of paragraph (b), and after that paragraph insert—

P3para.Text: bail-in compensation orders, and

P2para.Text: After section 81B insert—
The Bank of England may exercise a stabilisation power in respect of a banking group company in accordance with section 12A(2) if the following conditions are met.
Condition 1 is that the PRA is satisfied that the general conditions for the exercise of a stabilisation power set out in section 7 are met in respect of a bank in the same group.

P1para.Text: In this Schedule—

P3para.Text: “the Regulator” means the Payment Systems Regulator;
references to the functions of the Regulator are to functions conferred on it by or under this Part.

P2para.Text: The constitution of the Regulator must provide for it to have a board whose members are the directors of the Regulator.
The board is to consist of the following members—

P3para.Text: a member to chair it, appointed by the FCA with the approval of the Treasury;
a member to be the Managing Director, appointed by the FCA with the approval of the Treasury;
one or more other members appointed by the FCA.

P2para.Text: The persons who may be appointed under sub-paragraph (2) include persons who are members of the FCA’s governing body.
A person may be appointed under sub-paragraph (2) only if the person has knowledge or experience which is likely to be relevant to the exercise by the Regulator of its functions.
A person appointed under sub-paragraph (2)(a) or (b) is liable to removal from office by the FCA (acting with the approval of the Treasury).
A person appointed under sub-paragraph (2)(c) is liable to removal from office by the FCA.
The Regulator is not to be regarded as exercising functions on behalf of the Crown.
The officers and staff of the Regulator are not to be regarded as Crown servants.
The Regulator must adopt an annual budget which has been approved by the FCA.
The budget must be adopted—

P3para.Text: in the case of the Regulator’s first financial year, as soon as reasonably practicable after it is established, and
in the case of each subsequent financial year, before the start of the financial year.

P2para.Text: The Regulator may, with the approval of the FCA, vary the budget for a financial year at any time after its adoption.
Before adopting or varying a budget, the Regulator must consult—

P3para.Text: the Treasury, and
such other persons (if any) as the Regulator considers appropriate.

P2para.Text: The Regulator must publish each budget, and each variation of a budget, in the way it considers appropriate.
The Regulator may make arrangements for any of its functions to be discharged by—

P3para.Text: a committee, sub-committee, officer or member of staff of the Regulator;
an officer or member of staff of the FCA.

P2para.Text: This is subject to sub-paragraphs (2) to (4).
In exercising any functions within sub-paragraph (3), the Regulator must act through its board.
The functions referred to in sub-paragraph (2) are—

P3para.Text: giving general directions under section 44;
imposing requirements under section 45 that apply to all operators of regulated payment systems.

P2para.Text: The function of issuing general guidance may not be discharged by an officer or member of staff of the Regulator or of the FCA.
The Regulator must in respect of each of its financial years prepare an annual plan which has been approved by the FCA.
The plan must be prepared—

P3para.Text: in the case of the Regulator’s first financial year, as soon as reasonably practicable after it is established, and
in the case of each subsequent financial year, before the start of the financial year.

P2para.Text: The Regulator may, with the approval of the FCA, vary the plan in respect of a financial year at any time after its preparation.
An annual plan in respect of a financial year must set out—

P3para.Text: the aims of the Regulator for the year,
how the extent to which each of those aims is met is to be determined,
the relative priorities of each of those aims, and
how its resources are to be allocated among the activities to be carried on in connection with the discharge of its functions.

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (4) references to aims for a financial year include aims for a longer period that includes that year.
Before preparing or varying an annual plan, the Regulator must consult—

P3para.Text: the Treasury, and
such other persons (if any) as the Regulator considers appropriate.

P2para.Text: The Regulator must publish each annual plan, and each variation of an annual plan, in the way it considers appropriate.
At least once a year, the Regulator must make a report to the FCA in relation to the discharge of its functions.
The report must—

P3para.Text: set out the extent to which the Regulator has met its aims and priorities for the period covered by the report,
set out the extent to which the Regulator has advanced its payment systems objectives,
include a copy of its latest accounts, and
comply with any requirement specified in rules made by the FCA.

P2para.Text: The Regulator must publish each report in the way it considers appropriate.
Nothing in this paragraph requires the Regulator to make a report at any time in the period of 12 months beginning with its establishment.
The Treasury may—

P3para.Text: require the Regulator to comply with any provision of the Companies Act 2006 about accounts and their audit which would not otherwise apply to it, or

direct that any provision of that Act about accounts and their audit is to apply to the Regulator with such modifications as are specified in the direction, whether or not the provision would otherwise apply to it.

P2para.Text: Compliance with any requirement under sub-paragraph (5)(a) or (b) is enforceable by injunction or, in Scotland, an order for specific performance under section 45 of the Court of Session Act 1988.
Proceedings under sub-paragraph (6) may be brought only by the Treasury.

The FCA’s power to make rules under sub-paragraph (2)(d) is to be treated as if it were a power of the FCA to make rules under FSMA 2000 (and rules made under sub-paragraph (2)(d) are to be treated accordingly).
The Regulator must send a copy of its annual accounts to the Comptroller and Auditor General and the Treasury as soon as is reasonably practicable.
The Comptroller and Auditor General must—

P3para.Text: examine, certify and report on accounts received under this paragraph, and
send a copy of the certified accounts and the report to the Treasury.

P2para.Text: The Treasury must lay the copy of the certified accounts and the report before Parliament.
The Regulator must send a copy of the certified accounts and the report to the FCA.
Except as provided for by paragraph 7(5), the Regulator is exempt from the requirements of Part 16 of the Companies Act 2006 (audit) and its balance sheet must contain a statement to that effect.
In this paragraph “annual accounts” has the meaning given by section 471 of the Companies Act 2006.

P3para.Text: the expenses incurred, or expected to be incurred, by the Regulator in connection with the discharge of its functions,
the expenses incurred by the FCA in establishing the Regulator,
any other expenses incurred by the FCA in connection with the discharge of its functions under this Part, and

any expenses incurred, or expected to be incurred, by the FCA in connection with the discharge of the Regulator’s functions by an officer or member of staff of the FCA under arrangements made under paragraph 5.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of paragraph (b) it does not matter when the expenses were incurred.
For the purpose of meeting the relevant costs the FCA may make rules requiring participants in regulated payment systems to pay to the FCA specified amounts or amounts calculated in a specified way.
Before making any rules under sub-paragraph (2) the FCA must consult the Treasury.
The amounts to be paid under the rules may include a component to cover the expenses of the FCA in collecting the payments (“collection costs”).
The FCA must pay to the Regulator the amounts that it receives under the rules, apart from the following amounts (which it may keep)—

P3para.Text: amounts in respect of expenses falling within sub-paragraph (1)(b) to (d);
amounts in respect of its collection costs.

P2para.Text: In this paragraph “specified” means specified in the rules.
The FCA’s power to make rules under this paragraph is to be treated as if it were a power of the FCA to make rules under FSMA 2000 (and rules made under this paragraph are to be treated accordingly).
The Regulator must in respect of each of its financial years pay to the Treasury any amounts received by it during the year by way of penalties imposed under section 63.
The Treasury may give directions to the Regulator as to how it is to comply with its duty under sub-paragraph (1).
The directions may in particular—

P3para.Text: specify the time when any payment is required to be made to the Treasury, and
require the Regulator to provide the Treasury at specified times with information relating to penalties that the Regulator has imposed under section 63.

P2para.Text: The Treasury must pay into the Consolidated Fund any sums received by them under this paragraph.

P1para.Text: The Regulator must maintain satisfactory arrangements for—

P3para.Text: recording decisions made in the exercise of its functions, and
the safe-keeping of those records which it considers ought to be preserved.

P2para.Text: None of the following is to be liable in damages for anything done or omitted in the discharge, or purported discharge, of the Regulator’s functions—

P3para.Text: the Regulator;
any person (“P”) who is, or is acting as, an officer or member of staff of the Regulator;
any person who could be held vicariously liable for things done or omitted by P, but only in so far as the liability relates to P’s conduct.

P2para.Text: If the Regulator has made arrangements under paragraph 5 for any of its functions to be discharged by an officer or member of staff of the FCA, references in sub-paragraph (1) to a person who is an officer or member of staff of the Regulator include references to the officer or member of staff of the FCA.

Anything done or omitted by a person mentioned in sub-paragraph (1)(b) or (c) while acting, or purporting to act, as a result of an appointment under section 72 or 73 is to be taken for the purposes of sub-paragraph (1) to have been done or omitted in the discharge or (as the case may be) purported discharge of the Regulator’s functions.
Sub-paragraph (1) does not apply—

P3para.Text: if the act or omission is shown to have been in bad faith, or
so as to prevent an award of damages made in respect of an act or omission on the ground that the act or omission was unlawful as a result of section 6(1) of the Human Rights Act 1998.

TitleBlock.Title: Procedure for appeals to the CMA

P1group.Title: Functions of CMA to be discharged by group

P1para.Text: Except where specified otherwise in this Schedule, the functions of the CMA with respect to an appeal are to be carried out on behalf of the CMA by a group constituted for the purpose by the chair of the CMA under Schedule 4 to the Enterprise and Regulatory Reform Act 2013.

P2para.Text: Schedule 4 to the Enterprise and Regulatory Reform Act 2013 is amended as follows.
In paragraph 35(1) (membership of CMA panel), after paragraph (c) insert—

P3para.Text: at least one person (a “payment systems panel member”) appointed to the CMA panel under paragraph 1(1)(b) for the purpose of being available for selection as a member of a group constituted to carry out functions on behalf of the CMA with respect to an appeal made in accordance with section 69 of the Financial Services (Banking Reform) Act 2013 (a “specialist payment systems group”);

P2para.Text: In paragraph 38 (membership of CMA groups), after sub-paragraph (5) insert—
In the case of a specialist payment systems group, the group must include at least one payment systems member.
In paragraph 48 (performance of functions of chair with respect to constitution etc of CMA group), in sub-paragraph (4)(c), at the end insert—

P4para.Text: Schedule 5 to the Financial Services (Banking Reform) Act 2013.

P1group.Title: Application for permission to bring appeal

P2para.Text: An application for permission to bring an appeal may be made only by sending a notice to the CMA requesting the permission.
An application for permission to appeal must be accompanied by all such information as may be required by appeal rules.
Appeal rules may require information contained in an application for permission to appeal to be verified by a statement of truth.
A person who applies for permission to bring an appeal in accordance with this paragraph is referred to in this Schedule as the appellant.
The appellant must send the Payment Systems Regulator—

P3para.Text: a copy of the application for permission to appeal at the same time as it is sent to the CMA, and
such other information as may be required by appeal rules.

P2para.Text: The CMA’s decision whether to grant permission to appeal is to be taken by an authorised member of the CMA.

Before the authorised member decides whether to grant permission under this paragraph, the Payment Systems Regulator must be given an opportunity of making representations or observations, in accordance with paragraph 5(2).
The CMA’s decision on an application for permission must be made—

P3para.Text: where the Payment Systems Regulator makes representations or observations in accordance with paragraph 5(2), before the end of 10 working days beginning with the first working day after the day on which those representations or observations are received;
in any other case, before the end of 14 working days beginning with the first working day after the day on which the application for permission was received.

P2para.Text: The grant of permission may be made subject to conditions, which may include—

P3para.Text: conditions which limit the matters that are to be considered on the appeal in question;
conditions for the purpose of expediting the determination of the appeal;
conditions requiring the appeal to be considered together with other appeals (including appeals relating to different matters or decisions and appeals brought by different persons).

P2para.Text: Where a decision is made to grant or to refuse an application for permission, an authorised member of the CMA must notify the decision, giving reasons, to the following persons—

P3para.Text: the appellant, and
the Payment Systems Regulator.

P2para.Text: A decision of the CMA under this paragraph must be published, in such manner as an authorised member of the CMA considers appropriate, as soon as reasonably practicable after it is made.
The CMA may exclude from publication under sub-paragraph (11) any information which it is satisfied is—

P3para.Text: commercial information, the disclosure of which would, or might in the CMA’s opinion, significantly harm the legitimate business interests of an undertaking to which it relates, or
information relating to the private affairs of an individual, the disclosure of which would, or might in the CMA’s opinion, significantly harm the individual’s interests.

P2para.Text: The CMA may direct that, pending the determination of an appeal against a decision of the Payment Systems Regulator—

P3para.Text: the decision is not to have effect, or
the decision is not to have effect to such extent as may be specified in the direction.

P2para.Text: The power to give a direction under this paragraph is exercisable only where—

P3para.Text: an application for its exercise has been made by the appellant at the same time as the appellant made an application in accordance with paragraph 3 for permission to bring an appeal against a decision of the Payment Systems Regulator,
the Payment Systems Regulator has been given an opportunity of making representations or observations, in accordance with paragraph 5(2), and
the balance of convenience does not otherwise require effect to be given to the decision pending that determination.

P2para.Text: The CMA’s decision on an application for a direction under this paragraph must be made—

P3para.Text: where the Payment Systems Regulator makes representations or observations in accordance with paragraph 5(2), before the end of 10 working days beginning with the first working day after the day on which those representations or observations are received;
in any other case, before the end of 14 working days beginning with the first working day following the day on which the application under sub-paragraph (2)(a) is received.

P2para.Text: The appellant must send the Payment Systems Regulator a copy of the application for a direction under this paragraph at the same time as it is sent to the CMA.
The CMA’s decision whether to give a direction is to be taken by an authorised member of the CMA.
A direction under this paragraph must be—

P3para.Text: given by an authorised member of the CMA, and
published, in such manner as an authorised member of the CMA considers appropriate, as soon as reasonably practicable after it is given.

P2para.Text: Sub-paragraph (12) of paragraph 3 applies to the publication of a direction under sub-paragraph (6) of this paragraph as it applies to the publication of a decision under sub-paragraph (11) of that paragraph.

P1group.Title: Time limit for representations and observations by the Regulator

P2para.Text: Sub-paragraph (2) applies where the Payment Systems Regulator wishes to make representations or observations to the CMA in relation to—

P3para.Text: an application for permission to bring an appeal under paragraph 3;
an application for a direction under paragraph 4.

P2para.Text: The Payment Systems Regulator must make the representations or observations in writing before the end of 10 working days beginning with the first working day after the day on which it received a copy of the application under paragraph 3(5) or 4(4) (as the case may be).

Sub-paragraph (4) applies where an application for permission to bring an appeal has been granted and the Payment Systems Regulator wishes to make representations or observations to the CMA in relation to—

P3para.Text: the Payment Systems Regulator’s reasons for the decision in relation to which the appeal is being brought;
any grounds on which that appeal is being brought against that decision.

P2para.Text: The Payment Systems Regulator must make the representations or observations in writing before the end of 15 working days beginning with the first working day after the day on which permission to bring the appeal was granted.
The Payment Systems Regulator must send a copy of the representations and observations it makes under this paragraph to the appellant.

P1group.Title: Consideration and determination of appeal by group

P2para.Text: A group constituted by the chair of the CMA under Schedule 4 to the Enterprise and Regulatory Reform Act 2013 for the purpose of carrying out functions of the CMA with respect to an appeal must consist of three members of the CMA panel.
A decision of the group is effective if, and only if—

P3para.Text: all the members of the group are present when it is made, and
at least two members of the group are in favour of the decision.

P2para.Text: The CMA must determine an appeal within the period of 6 months beginning with the permission date.
If—

P3para.Text: the CMA has received representations on the timing of the determination from a party to the appeal, and
it is satisfied that there are special reasons why the determination cannot be made within the period specified in sub-paragraph (1),

P2para.Text: the CMA must determine the appeal within the period specified by it, which must not be longer than the period of 7 months beginning with the permission date.
In a case where sub-paragraph (2) applies, the CMA must also—

P3para.Text: inform the parties to the appeal of the time limit for determining the appeal, and
publish that time limit in such manner as it considers appropriate for the purpose of bringing it to the attention of any other persons likely to be affected by the determination.

P2para.Text: In this paragraph the “permission date” is the date on which the CMA gave permission to bring the appeal in accordance with section 66(8).

P1group.Title: Matters to be considered on appeal

P2para.Text: The CMA, if it thinks it necessary to do so for the purpose of securing the determination of an appeal within the period provided for by paragraph 7, may disregard—

P3para.Text: any or all matters raised by an appellant that were not raised by that appellant at the time of the relevant application, and
any or all matters raised by the Payment Systems Regulator that were not contained in representations or observations made for the purposes of the appeal in accordance with paragraph 5.

P2para.Text: In this paragraph “relevant application” means an application under paragraph 3 or 4.
For the purposes of this Schedule, the CMA may by notice—

P3para.Text: require a person to produce to the CMA the documents specified or otherwise identified in the notice;
require any person who carries on a business to supply to the CMA such estimates, forecasts, returns or other information as may be specified or described in the notice in relation to that business.

P2para.Text: The power to require the production of a document, or the supply of any estimate, forecast, return or other information, is a power to require its production or, as the case may be, supply—

P3para.Text: at the time and place specified in the notice, and
in a legible form.

P2para.Text: No person is to be compelled under this paragraph to produce a document or supply an estimate, forecast, return or other information which the person could not be compelled to produce in civil proceedings in the High Court or Court of Session.

An authorised member of the CMA may, for the purpose of the exercise of the functions of the CMA, make arrangements for copies to be taken of a document produced or an estimate, forecast, return or other information supplied to it under this paragraph.
A notice for the purposes of this paragraph—

P3para.Text: may be issued on the CMA’s behalf by an authorised member of the CMA;
must include information about the possible consequences of not complying with the notice (as set out in paragraph 13).

P2para.Text: For the purposes of this Schedule an oral hearing may be held, and evidence may be taken on oath—

P3para.Text: by a person considering an application for permission to bring an appeal under paragraph 3,
by a person considering an application for a direction under paragraph 4, or
by a group with the function of determining an appeal;

P2para.Text: and, for that purpose, such a person or group may administer oaths.
The CMA may by notice require a person—

P3para.Text: to attend at a time and place specified in the notice, and
at that time and place, to give evidence to a person or group mentioned in sub-paragraph (1).

P2para.Text: At any oral hearing the person or group conducting the hearing may—

P3para.Text: require the appellant or the Payment Systems Regulator, if present at the hearing, to give evidence or to make representations or observations, or
require a person attending the hearing as a representative of the appellant or of the Payment Systems Regulator to make representations or observations.

P2para.Text: A person who gives oral evidence at the hearing may be cross-examined by or on behalf of any party to the appeal.
If the appellant, the Payment Systems Regulator, or the appellant’s or Payment Systems Regulator’s representative is not present at a hearing—

P3para.Text: there is no requirement to give notice to that person under sub-paragraph (2), and
the person or group conducting the hearing may determine the application or appeal without hearing that person’s evidence, representations or observations.

P2para.Text: No person is to be compelled under this paragraph to give evidence which the person could not be compelled to give in civil proceedings in the High Court or Court of Session.

Where a person is required under this paragraph to attend at a place more than 10 miles from the person’s place of residence, an authorised member of the CMA must arrange for the person to be paid the necessary expenses of attendance.
A notice for the purposes of this paragraph may be issued on the CMA’s behalf by an authorised member of the CMA.
The CMA may by notice require a person to produce a written statement with respect to a matter specified in the notice to—

P3para.Text: a person who is considering, or is to consider, an application for a direction under paragraph 4, or
a group with the function of determining an appeal.

P2para.Text: The power to require the production of a written statement includes power—

P3para.Text: to specify the time and place at which it is to be produced, and
to require it to be verified by a statement of truth;

P2para.Text: and a statement required to be so verified must be disregarded unless it is so verified.

No person is to be compelled under this paragraph to produce a written statement with respect to any matter about which the person could not be compelled to give evidence in civil proceedings in the High Court or Court of Session.
A notice for the purposes of this paragraph may be issued on the CMA’s behalf by an authorised member of the CMA.

P1para.Text: Where permission to bring an appeal is granted under paragraph 3, the CMA may commission expert advice with respect to any matter raised by a party to the appeal.

P2para.Text: If a person (“the defaulter”)—

P3para.Text: fails to comply with a notice issued or other requirement imposed under paragraph 9, 10 or 11,
in complying with a notice under paragraph 11, makes a statement that is false in any material particular, or
in providing information verified in accordance with a statement of truth required by appeal rules, provides information that is false in a material particular,

P2para.Text: an authorised member of the CMA may certify that fact to the court.

If the court is satisfied that the defaulter failed without reasonable excuse to comply with the notice or other requirement, or made the false statement, or provided the false information, it may deal with the defaulter (and in the case of a body corporate, any director or other officer of the body) as if that person were in contempt.
In sub-paragraph (2) “officer”, in relation to a limited liability partnership, means a member of the limited liability partnership.
In this paragraph “court” means—

P3para.Text: the High Court, or
in Scotland, the Court of Session.

P2para.Text: A person who wilfully alters, suppresses or destroys a document which the person has been required to produce under paragraph 9 is guilty of an offence.
A person guilty of an offence under this paragraph is liable—

P3para.Text: on summary conviction—

P4para.Text: in England and Wales, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months (or 6 months, if the offence was committed before the commencement of section 154(1) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003) or a fine, or both;
in Scotland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months or a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum, or both;
in Northern Ireland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum, or both;

P3para.Text: on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 2 years or a fine, or both.

P2para.Text: A determination by the CMA on an appeal—

P3para.Text: must be contained in an order made by the CMA;
must set out the reasons for the determination;
takes effect at the time specified in the order or determined in accordance with provision made in the order;
must be notified by the CMA to the parties to the appeal;
must be published by the CMA—

P4para.Text: as soon as reasonably practicable after the determination is made;
in such manner as the CMA considers appropriate for the purpose of bringing the determination to the attention of any person likely to be affected by it (other than a party to the appeal).

P2para.Text: The CMA may exclude from publication under sub-paragraph (1)(e) any information which it is satisfied is—

P3para.Text: commercial information, the disclosure of which would, or might in the CMA’s opinion, significantly harm the legitimate business interests of an undertaking to which it relates, or
information relating to the private affairs of an individual, the disclosure of which would, or might in the CMA’s opinion, significantly harm the individual’s interests.

P2para.Text: The Payment Systems Regulator must take such steps as it considers necessary for it to comply with an order of the CMA made by virtue of sub-paragraph (1)(a).
The steps must be taken—

P3para.Text: if a time is specified in (or is to be determined in accordance with) the order, within that time;
in any other case, within a reasonable time.

P2para.Text: The CMA Board may make rules of procedure regulating the conduct and disposal of appeals.

Those rules may include provision supplementing the provisions of this Schedule in relation to any application, notice, hearing, power or requirement for which this Schedule provides; and that provision may, in particular, impose time limits or other restrictions on—

P3para.Text: the taking of evidence at an oral hearing, or
the making of representations or observations at such a hearing.

P2para.Text: The CMA Board must publish rules made under this paragraph in such manner as it considers appropriate for the purpose of bringing them to the attention of those likely to be affected by them.
Before making rules under this paragraph, the CMA Board must consult such persons as it considers appropriate.
Rules under this paragraph may make different provision for different cases.
A group that determines an appeal must make an order requiring the payment to the CMA of the costs incurred by the CMA in connection with the appeal.
An order under sub-paragraph (1) must require those costs to be paid—

P3para.Text: where the appeal is allowed in full, by the Payment Systems Regulator;
where the appeal is dismissed in full, by the appellant;
where the appeal is partially allowed, by one or more parties in such proportions as the CMA considers appropriate in all the circumstances.

P2para.Text: The group that determines an appeal may also make such order as it thinks fit for requiring a party to the appeal to make payments to another party in respect of costs reasonably incurred by that other party in connection with the appeal.

A person who is required by an order under this paragraph to pay a sum to another person must comply with the order before the end of the period of 28 days beginning with the day after the making of the order.

Sums required to be paid by an order under this paragraph but not paid within the period mentioned in sub-paragraph (4) are to bear interest at such rate as may be determined in accordance with provision contained in the order.
Any costs payable by virtue of an order under this paragraph and any interest that has not been paid may be recovered as a civil debt by the person in whose favour the order is made.
In this Schedule—

Para.Text: “appeal” means an appeal made in accordance with section 69;
“appeal rules” means rules of procedure under paragraph 16;
“authorised member of the CMA”—

in relation to a power exercisable in connection with an appeal in respect of which a group has been constituted by the chair of the CMA under Schedule 4 to the Enterprise and Regulatory Reform Act 2013, means a member of that group who has been authorised by the chair of the CMA to exercise that power;
in relation to a power exercisable in connection with an application for permission to bring an appeal, or otherwise in
connection with an appeal in respect of which a group has not been so constituted by the chair of the CMA, means—
any member of the CMA Board who is also a member of the CMA panel, or
any member of the CMA panel authorised by the Treasury (whether generally or specifically) to exercise the power in question;
“CMA” means the Competition and Markets Authority;
“CMA Board” and “CMA panel” have the same meaning as in Schedule 4 to the Enterprise and Regulatory Reform Act 2013;
“group” means a group selected in accordance with paragraph 6;

“statement of truth”, in relation to the production of a statement or provision of information by a person, means a statement that the person believes the facts stated in the statement or information to be true;
“working day” means any day other than—
Saturday or Sunday;
Christmas Day or Good Friday;
a day which is a bank holiday under the Banking and Financial Dealings Act 1971 in any part of the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: References in this Schedule to a party to an appeal are references to—

P3para.Text: the appellant, or
the Payment Systems Regulator.

P1para.Text: The following provisions of this Schedule provide for—

P3para.Text: the general powers and duties of FMI administrators (by application of provisions about administrators), and
the general process and effects of FMI administration (by application of provisions about administration).

P1para.Text: The provisions set out in the Tables apply in relation to FMI administration as in relation to administration, with—

P3para.Text: the modifications set out in paragraph 3,
any other modification specified in the Tables, and
any other necessary modification.

P1para.Text: The modifications are that—

P3para.Text: a reference to the administrator is a reference to the FMI administrator,
a reference to administration is a reference to FMI administration,
a reference to an administration application is a reference to an FMI administration application,
a reference to an administration order is a reference to an FMI administration order,
a reference to a company is a reference to the infrastructure company, and
a reference to the purpose of administration (other than the reference in paragraph 111(1) of Schedule B1) is a reference to the objective in section 100.

P1para.Text: Powers conferred by this Part of this Act and by the 1986 Act (as applied) are in addition to, and not in restriction of, any existing powers of instituting proceedings against any contributory or debtor of an infrastructure company, or the estate of any contributory or debtor, for the recovery of any call or other sum.
A reference in an enactment or other document to anything done under a provision applied by this Part of this Act includes a reference to the provision as applied.

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by order amend this Schedule so as to make further modifications.
The further modifications that may be made are confined to such modifications of—

P3para.Text: the 1986 Act, or
other enactments passed or made before this Act that relate to insolvency or make provision by reference to anything that is or may be done under the 1986 Act,

P2para.Text: as the Treasury consider appropriate in relation to any provision made by or under this Part of this Act.
An order under this paragraph may also make modifications of the provisions of this Schedule.

P1para.Text: This Schedule applies where—

P3para.Text: the court has made an FMI administration order in relation to a company (“the old company”), and
it is proposed that a transfer within section 100(5) be made to another company (“the new company”).

P1para.Text: In this Schedule—

Para.Text: “FMI transfer scheme” has the meaning given by paragraph 4(1);
“the new company” and “the old company” are to be read in accordance with paragraph 1;
“third party”, in relation to an FMI transfer scheme or a modification of such a scheme, means a person other than the old company or the new company.

P1group.Title: FMI administrator to act on behalf of old company

P1para.Text: It is for the FMI administrator, while the FMI administration order is in force, to act on behalf of the old company in the doing of anything that it is authorised or required to do by or under this Schedule.

It is for the FMI administrator, while the FMI administration order is in force, to act on behalf of the old company in the doing of anything that it is authorised or required to do by or under this Schedule.

P2para.Text: The old company may—

P3para.Text: with the consent of the new company, and
for the purpose of giving effect to the proposed transfer,

P2para.Text: make a scheme under this Schedule for the transfer of property, rights and liabilities from the old company to the new company (an “FMI transfer scheme”).
Such a scheme may be made only at a time when the FMI administration order is in force in relation to the old company.
An FMI transfer scheme may set out the property, rights and liabilities to be transferred in one or more of the following ways—

P3para.Text: by specifying or describing them in particular,
by identifying them generally by reference to, or to a specified part of, the undertaking of the old company, or
by specifying the manner in which they are to be determined.

P2para.Text: An FMI transfer scheme is to take effect in accordance with paragraph 7 at the time appointed by the court.
But the court must not appoint a time for a scheme to take effect unless that scheme has been approved by the Bank of England.
The Bank of England may modify an FMI transfer scheme before approving it, but only modifications to which both the old company and the new company have consented may be made.
In deciding whether to approve an FMI transfer scheme, the Bank of England must have regard, in particular, to—

P3para.Text: the public interest, and
any effect that the scheme is likely to have on the interests of third parties.

P2para.Text: Before approving an FMI transfer scheme, the Bank of England must consult the Treasury.
The old company and the new company each have a duty to provide the Bank of England with all information and other assistance that the Bank may
reasonably require for the purposes of, or in connection with, the exercise of the powers conferred on it by this paragraph.

P1group.Title: Provision that may be made by a scheme

P2para.Text: An FMI transfer scheme may contain provision—

P3para.Text: for the creation, in favour of the old company or the new company, of an interest or right in or in relation to property transferred in accordance with the scheme;
for giving effect to a transfer to the new company by the creation, in favour of that company, of an interest or right in or in relation to property retained by the old company;
for the creation of new rights and liabilities (including rights of indemnity and duties to indemnify) as between the old company and the new company;

in connection with any provision made under this sub-paragraph, provision making incidental provision as to the interests, rights and liabilities of other persons with respect to the property, rights and liabilities to which the scheme relates.

P2para.Text: The property, rights and liabilities of the old company that may be transferred in accordance with an FMI transfer scheme include—

P3para.Text: property, rights and liabilities that would not otherwise be capable of being transferred or assigned by the old company;
property acquired, and rights and liabilities arising, in the period after the making of the scheme but before it takes effect;
rights and liabilities arising after it takes effect in respect of matters occurring before it takes effect;
property situated anywhere in the United Kingdom or elsewhere;
rights and liabilities under the law of a part of the United Kingdom or of a place outside the United Kingdom;
rights and liabilities under an enactment, EU instrument or subordinate legislation.

P2para.Text: The transfers to which effect may be given by an FMI transfer scheme include transfers of interests and rights that are to take effect in accordance with the scheme as if there were—

P3para.Text: no such requirement to obtain a person’s consent or concurrence,
no such liability in respect of a contravention of any other requirement, and
no such interference with any interest or right,

P2para.Text: as there would be, in the case of a transaction apart from this Act, by reason of a provision falling within sub-paragraph (4).

A provision falls within this sub-paragraph to the extent that it has effect (whether under an enactment or agreement or otherwise) in relation to the terms on which the old company is entitled, or subject, to anything to which the transfer relates.

Sub-paragraph (6) applies where (apart from that sub-paragraph) a person would be entitled, in consequence of anything done or likely to be done by or under this Act in connection with an FMI transfer scheme—

P3para.Text: to terminate, modify, acquire or claim an interest or right, or
to treat an interest or right as modified or terminated.

P2para.Text: That entitlement—

P3para.Text: is not enforceable in relation to that interest or right until after the transfer of the interest or right by the scheme, and
is then enforceable in relation to the interest or right only in so far as the scheme contains provision for the interest or right to be transferred subject to whatever confers that entitlement.

P2para.Text: Sub-paragraphs (3) to (6) have effect where shares in a subsidiary of the old company are transferred—

P3para.Text: as if the reference in sub-paragraph (4) to the terms on which the old company is entitled or subject to anything to which the transfer relates included a reference to the terms on which the subsidiary is entitled or subject to anything immediately before the transfer takes effect, and
in relation to an interest or right of the subsidiary, as if the references in sub-paragraph (6)to the transfer of the interest or right included a reference to the transfer of the shares.

P2para.Text: Sub-paragraphs (3) and (4) apply to the creation of an interest or right by an FMI transfer scheme as they apply to the transfer of an interest or right.
An FMI transfer scheme may make incidental, supplemental, consequential and transitional provision in connection with the other provisions of the scheme.
An FMI transfer scheme may in particular make provision, in relation to a provision of the scheme—

P3para.Text: for the new company to be treated as the same person in law as the old company;

for agreements made, transactions effected or other things done by or in relation to the old company to be treated, so far as may be necessary for the purposes of or in connection with a transfer in accordance with the scheme, as made, effected or done by or in relation to the new company;

for references in an agreement, instrument or other document to the old company or to an employee or office holder with the old company to have effect, so far as may be necessary for the purposes of or in connection with a transfer in accordance with the scheme, with such modifications as are specified in the scheme;

that the effect of any transfer in accordance with the scheme in relation to contracts of employment with the old company is not to terminate any of those contracts but is to be that periods of employment with that company are to count for all purposes as periods of employment with the new company;
for proceedings commenced by or against the old company to be continued by or against the new company.

P2para.Text: Sub-paragraph (2)(c) does not apply to references in an enactment or in subordinate legislation.

An FMI transfer scheme may make provision for disputes between the old company and the new company as to the effect of the scheme to be referred to such arbitration as may be specified in or determined under the scheme.

Where a person is entitled, in consequence of an FMI transfer scheme, to possession of a document relating in part to the title to land or other property in England and Wales, or to the management of such land or other property—

P3para.Text: the scheme may provide for that person to be treated as having given another person an acknowledgement in writing of the right of that other person to production of the document and to delivery of copies of it, and

section 64 of the Law of Property Act 1925 (production and safe custody of documents) is to have effect accordingly, and on the basis that the acknowledgement did not contain an expression of contrary intention.

P2para.Text: Where a person is entitled, in consequence of an FMI transfer scheme, to possession of a document relating in part to the title to land or other property in Scotland or to the management of such land or other property, subsections (1) and (2) of section 16 of the Land Registration (Scotland) Act 1979 (omission of certain clauses in deeds) is to have effect in relation to the transfer—

P3para.Text: as if the transfer had been effected by deed, and
as if the words “unless specially qualified” were omitted from each of those subsections.

P2para.Text: Where a person is entitled, in consequence of an FMI transfer scheme, to possession of a document relating in part to the title to land or other property in Northern Ireland or to the management of such land or other property—

P3para.Text: the scheme may provide for that person to be treated as having given another person an acknowledgement in writing of the right of that other person to production of the document and to delivery of copies of it, and
section 9 of the Conveyancing Act 1881 is to have effect accordingly, and on the basis that the acknowledgement does not contain an expression of contrary intention.

P2para.Text: In this paragraph references to a transfer in accordance with an FMI transfer scheme include references to the creation in accordance with such a scheme of an interest, right or liability.
In relation to each provision of an FMI transfer scheme for the transfer of property, rights or liabilities, or for the creation of interests, rights or liabilities—

P3para.Text: the property, interests, rights or liabilities become by virtue of this Schedule the property, interests, rights or liabilities of the transferee at the time appointed by the court for the purposes of paragraph 4(4), and
the provisions of that scheme in relation to that property, or those interests, rights or liabilities, have effect from that time.

P2para.Text: In this paragraph “the transferee” means—

P3para.Text: in relation to property, rights or liabilities transferred by an FMI transfer scheme, the new company;
in relation to interests, rights or liabilities created by such a scheme, the person in whose favour, or in relation to whom, they are created.

P2para.Text: The Bank of England may by notice to the old company and the new company modify an FMI transfer scheme after it has taken effect, but only modifications to which both the old company and the new company have consented may be made.
The notice must specify the time at which it is to take effect (the “modification time”).

Where a notice is issued under this paragraph in relation to an FMI transfer scheme, as from the modification time, the scheme is for all purposes to be treated as having taken effect, at the time appointed for the purposes of paragraph 4(4), with the modifications made by the notice.
Those modifications may make—

P3para.Text: any provision that could have been included in the scheme when it took effect at the time appointed for the purposes of paragraph 4(4), and
transitional provision in connection with provision falling within paragraph (a).

P2para.Text: In deciding whether to modify an FMI transfer scheme, the Bank of England must have regard, in particular, to—

P3para.Text: the public interest, and
any effect that the modification is likely to have on the interests of third parties.

P2para.Text: Before modifying an FMI transfer scheme that has taken effect, the Bank of England must consult the Treasury.

The old company and the new company each have a duty to provide the Bank of England with all information and other assistance that the Bank may reasonably require for the purposes of, or in connection with, the exercise of the powers conferred on it by this paragraph.
An FMI transfer scheme may contain provision about—

P3para.Text: the transfer of foreign property, right and liabilities, and
the creation of foreign property, rights and liabilities.

P2para.Text: For this purpose property, or a right, interest or liability, is “foreign” if an issue relating to it arising in any proceedings would (in accordance with the rules of private international law) be determined under the law of a country or territory outside the United Kingdom.
