P1group.Title: The FCA’s functions under Part 4 of the Enterprise Act 2002

P2para.Text: The functions to which this subsection applies (“the concurrent functions”) are to be concurrent functions of the FCA and the Competition and Markets Authority (referred to in this Part as “the CMA”).
Subsection (1) applies to the functions of the CMA under Part 4 of the Enterprise Act 2002 (market investigations), so far as those functions—

P3para.Text: are exercisable by the CMA Board (within the meaning of Schedule 4 to the Enterprise and Regulatory Reform Act 2013), and
relate to financial sector activities.

P2para.Text: But subsection (1) does not apply to functions under the following sections of the Enterprise Act 2002—

P3para.Text: section 166 (duty to maintain register of undertakings and orders);
section 171 (duty to publish guidance).

P2para.Text: So far as is necessary for the purposes of, or in connection with, subsections (1) and (2)—

P3para.Text: references in Part 4 of the Enterprise Act 2002 to the CMA (including references in provisions of that Act applied by that Part) are to be read as including references to the FCA, and
references in that Part to section 5 of that Act are to be read as including references to section 234N of this Act.

P2para.Text: But subsection (4) does not apply—

P3para.Text: in relation to section 166 or 171 of that Act, or
where the context otherwise requires.

P2para.Text: Section 130A of the Enterprise Act 2002 has effect in relation to the FCA by virtue of subsections (1) and (2) as if—

P3para.Text: in subsection (2)(a) of that section, the reference to the acquisition or supply of goods or services of one or more than one description in the United Kingdom were a reference to financial sector activities involving services provided or received in the United Kingdom, and

in subsection (2)(b) of that section, the reference to the extent to which steps can and should be taken were a reference to the extent to which steps that might include steps under Part 4 of that Act can and should be taken.

P2para.Text: Before the CMA or the FCA first exercises any of the concurrent functions in relation to any matter, it must consult the other.
Neither the CMA nor the FCA may exercise any of the concurrent functions in relation to any matter if any of those functions have been exercised in relation to that matter by the other.

P1group.Title: The FCA’s functions under the Competition Act 1998

P2para.Text: The functions to which this subsection applies are to be concurrent functions of the FCA and the CMA.
Subsection (1) applies to the functions of the CMA under the provisions of Part 1 of the Competition Act 1998, so far as relating to any of the following that relate to financial sector activities—

P3para.Text: agreements, decisions or concerted practices of the kind mentioned in section 2(1) of that Act,
conduct of the kind mentioned in section 18(1) of that Act,
agreements, decisions or concerted practices of the kind mentioned in Article 101(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and
conduct which amounts to abuse of the kind mentioned in Article 102 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

P2para.Text: But subsection (1) does not apply to functions under the following provisions of that Act—

P3para.Text: section 31D(1) to (6) (duty to publish guidance);
section 38(1) to (6) (duty to publish guidance about penalties);
section 40B(1) to (4) (duty to publish statement of policy on penalties);
section 51 (rules).

P2para.Text: So far as necessary for the purposes of, or in connection with, the provisions of subsections (1) and (2), references to the CMA in Part 1 of the Competition Act 1998 are to be read as including references to the FCA.
But subsection (4) does not apply—

P3para.Text: in relation to sections 31D(1) to (6), 38(1) to (6), 40B(1) to (4), 51, 52(6) and (8) and 54 of that Act, or
where the context otherwise requires.

P1group.Title: Duty to consider exercise of powers under Competition Act 1998

P2para.Text: Before exercising a power listed in subsection (3), the FCA must consider whether it would be more appropriate to proceed under the Competition Act 1998.
The FCA must not exercise such a power if it considers that it would be more appropriate to proceed under the Competition Act 1998.
Those powers are—

P3para.Text: the power under section 55J(2) to vary or cancel a Part 4A permission;
the power under section 55L to impose a requirement on an authorised person with a Part 4A permission, or to vary a requirement imposed under that section;
the power to take action under section 88E;
the power to take action under section 89U;
the power to give a direction under section 192C;
the power to impose a requirement under section 196.

P1group.Title: Provision of information and assistance to a CMA group

P2para.Text: For the purpose of assisting a CMA group in carrying out a relevant investigation, the FCA must give the CMA group—

P3para.Text: any relevant information which the FCA has in its possession, and
any other assistance which the CMA group may reasonably require in relation to any matters falling within the scope of the investigation.

P2para.Text: A “relevant investigation” is an investigation carried out on a reference made by the FCA under section 131 of the Enterprise Act 2002 by virtue of section 234J.
“Relevant information”, in relation to a relevant investigation, is information—

P3para.Text: which relates to matters falling within the scope of the investigation, and
which—

P4para.Text: is requested by the CMA group for the purpose of the investigation, or
in the FCA’s opinion, it would be appropriate to give to the CMA group for that purpose.

P2para.Text: A CMA group, in carrying out a relevant investigation, must take into account any information given to it under this section.
In this section “CMA group” has the same meaning as in Schedule 4 to the Enterprise and Regulatory Reform Act 2013.

P1group.Title: Function of keeping market under review

P2para.Text: For the purpose of the functions conferred on it by sections 234J to 234M the FCA is to have the function of keeping under review the market for financial services.

The function conferred by subsection (1) is to be carried out with a view to (among other things) ensuring that the FCA has sufficient information to take informed decisions and to carry out its other functions effectively.
Section 1B (the FCA’s general duties) does not apply in relation to anything done by the FCA in the carrying out of its functions by virtue of sections 234J to 234M.

But in the carrying out of any functions by virtue of sections 234J to 234M, the FCA may have regard to any of the matters in respect of which a duty is imposed by section 1B if it is a matter to which the CMA is entitled to have regard in the carrying out of those functions.

If any question arises as to whether, by virtue of section 234J or 234K, any functions fall to be, or are capable of being, carried out by the FCA in relation to any particular case, that question is to be referred to, and determined by, the Treasury.

No objection is to be taken to anything done under the Competition Act 1998 or Part 4 of the Enterprise Act 2002 by or in relation to the FCA on the ground that it should have been done by or in relation to the CMA.

The year-end date of a building society established on or after the relevant day is the last day of the month in which the anniversary of its establishment falls.
The financial year of a building society established before the relevant day is the period of 12 months ending with the year-end date of the society (but see subsection (1G)).
In the case of a building society established on or after the relevant day—

P3para.Text: the initial financial year of the society shall be the period of more than 6 months, but not more than 18 months, beginning with the date of its establishment and ending with its year-end date, and
its subsequent financial years are successive periods of 12 months beginning immediately after the end of the previous financial year and ending with its year-end date (but see subsection (1G)).

P2para.Text: The final financial year of a building society is a period of less than 12 months that begins immediately after the end of the previous financial year and ends with the date as at which the society makes up its final accounts.
This section has effect subject to section 117A (alteration of financial year).
Omit subsections (2) and (3).

P2para.Text: A building society may by notice given to the FCA specify a new year-end date.
A notice given under subsection (1) has effect in relation to—

P3para.Text: the financial year in which the notice is given (“the current financial year”), and
subsequent financial years.

P2para.Text: The notice must state whether the current financial year—

P3para.Text: is to be shortened, so as to come to an end on the first occasion on which the new year-end date falls or fell after the beginning of the current financial year, or
is to be extended, so as to come to an end on the second occasion on which that date falls or fell after the beginning of the current financial year.

P2para.Text: A notice extending a building society’s financial year is not effective if given less than 5 years after the end of an earlier financial year of the society that was extended under this section.

A financial year of a building society may not be extended so as to exceed 18 months and a notice under subsection (1) is ineffective if the current financial year as extended in accordance with the notice would exceed that limit.
